In particular, under an appropriate decay assumption on the weight function K at infinity and a growth restriction on the nonlinearity f , we establish the existence of a positive weak solution <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>‚àà</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mi>C</m:mi><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:msup><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mover><m:msup><m:mi>Œ©</m:mi><m:mi>e</m:mi></m:msup><m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo></m:mover><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:math> {u\in C^{1}(\overline{\Omega^{e}})} with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn></m:mrow></m:math> {u=0} pointwise on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo><m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo><m:mi>Œ©</m:mi></m:mrow></m:math> {\partial\Omega} . Further, under an additional assumption on f , we conclude that our solution is unique. Consequently, when Œ© is a ball in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:msup></m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} , for certain classes of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>K</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>K</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>|</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo>|</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:math> {K(x)=K(|x|)} , we observe that our solution must also be radial.

title: Null controllability for a degenerate population model in divergence form via Carleman estimates
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider a degenerate population equation in divergence form depending on time, on age and on space and we prove a related null controllability result via Carleman estimates.

title: Large data existence theory for three-dimensional unsteady flows of rate-type viscoelastic fluids with stress diffusion
authors: Michal Bathory; Miroslav Bul√≠ƒçek; Josef M√°lek
abstract: Abstract We prove that there exists a weak solution to a system governing an unsteady flow of a viscoelastic fluid in three dimensions, for arbitrarily large time interval and data. The fluid is described by the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations for the velocity v , coupled with a diffusive variant of a combination of the Oldroyd-B and the Giesekus models for a tensor ùîπ. By a proper choice of the constitutive relations for the Helmholtz free energy (which, however, is non-standard in the current literature, despite the fact that this choice is well motivated from the point of view of physics) and for the energy dissipation, we are able to prove that ùîπ enjoys the same regularity as v in the classical three-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations. This enables us to handle any kind of objective derivative of ùîπ, thus obtaining existence results for the class of diffusive Johnson-Segalman models as well. Moreover, using a suitable approximation scheme, we are able to show that ùîπ remains positive definite if the initial datum was a positive definite matrix (in a pointwise sense). We also show how the model we are considering can be derived from basic balance equations and thermodynamical principles in a natural way.

title: Weak and stationary solutions to a Cahn‚ÄìHilliard‚ÄìBrinkman model with singular potentials and source terms
abstract: Abstract We study a phase field model proposed recently in the context of tumour growth. The model couples a Cahn‚ÄìHilliard‚ÄìBrinkman (CHB) system with an elliptic reaction-diffusion equation for a nutrient. The fluid velocity, governed by the Brinkman law, is not solenoidal, as its divergence is a function of the nutrient and the phase field variable, i.e., solution-dependent, and frictionless boundary conditions are prescribed for the velocity to avoid imposing unrealistic constraints on the divergence relation. In this paper we give a first result on the existence of weak and stationary solutions to the CHB model for tumour growth with singular potentials, specifically the double obstacle potential and the logarithmic potential, which ensures that the phase field variable stays in the physically relevant interval. New difficulties arise from the interplay between the singular potentials and the solution-dependent source terms, but can be overcome with several key estimates for the approximations of the singular potentials, which maybe of independent interest. As a consequence, included in our analysis is an existence result for a Darcy variant, and our work serves to generalise recent results on weak and stationary solutions to the Cahn‚ÄìHilliard inpainting model with singular potentials.

title: Constant sign and nodal solutions for superlinear (p, q)‚Äìequations with indefinite potential and a concave boundary term
abstract: Abstract We consider a nonlinear elliptic equation driven by the ( p , q )‚ÄìLaplacian plus an indefinite potential. The reaction is ( p ‚àí 1)‚Äìsuperlinear and the boundary term is parametric and concave. Using variational tools from the critical point theory together with truncation, perturbation and comparison techniques and critical groups, we show that for all small values of the parameter, the problem has at least five nontrivial smooth solutions, all with sign information and which are linearly ordered.

The exponent <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"><m:mtr><m:mtd><m:mstyle displaystyle="true"><m:mfrac><m:mi>Œ±</m:mi><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mfrac><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mstyle></m:mtd></m:mtr></m:mtable></m:math> $\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \frac{\alpha}{2}+1 \end{array}$ is critical with respect to the Hardy-Littlewood-Sobolev inequality. We obtain the existence of a nontrivial solution or a Nehari-type ground state solution for the above equation in the doubly critical case, i.e. the appearance of both the lower critical exponent <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"><m:mtr><m:mtd><m:mstyle displaystyle="true"><m:mfrac><m:mi>Œ±</m:mi><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mfrac><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mstyle></m:mtd></m:mtr></m:mtable></m:math> $\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \frac{\alpha}{2}+1 \end{array}$ and the critical exponential growth of f ( u ).

title: Regularity of stable solutions to semilinear elliptic equations on Riemannian models
abstract: We consider the reaction-diffusion problem $-\Delta_g u = f(u)$ in $\mathcal{B}_R$ with zero Dirichlet boundary condition, posed in a geodesic ball $\mathcal{B}_R$ with radius $R$ of a Riemannian model $(M,g)$. This class of Riemannian manifolds includes the classical \textit{space forms}, i.e., the Euclidean, elliptic, and hyperbolic spaces. For the class of semistable solutions we prove radial symmetry and monotonicity. Furthermore, we establish $L^\infty$, $L^p$, and $W^{1,p}$ estimates which are optimal and do not depend on the nonlinearity $f$. As an application, under standard assumptions on the nonlinearity $\lambda f(u)$, we prove that the corresponding extremal solution $u^*$ is bounded whenever $n\leq9$. To establish the optimality of our regularity results we find the extremal solution for some exponential and power nonlinearities using an improved weighted Hardy inequality.

title: Zero mass case for a fractional Berestycki‚ÄìLions-type problem

title: Existence results for nonlinear elliptic problems on fractal domains
abstract: Abstract Some existence results for a parametric Dirichlet problem defined on the Sierpi≈Ñski fractal are proved. More precisely, a critical point result for differentiable functionals is exploited in order to prove the existence of a well-determined open interval of positive eigenvalues for which the problem admits at least one non-trivial weak solution.

title: On sign-changing solutions for (p,q)-Laplace equations with two parameters
abstract: Abstract We investigate the existence of nodal (sign-changing) solutions to the Dirichlet problem for a two-parametric family of partially homogeneous <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {(p,q)} -Laplace equations <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {-\Delta_{p}u-\Delta_{q}u=\alpha\lvert u\rvert^{p-2}u+\beta\lvert u\rvert^{q-2% }u} where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â†</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {p\neq q} . By virtue of the Nehari manifolds, the linking theorem, and descending flow, we explicitly characterize subsets of the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {(\alpha,\beta)} -plane which correspond to the existence of nodal solutions. In each subset the obtained solutions have prescribed signs of energy and, in some cases, exactly two nodal domains. The nonexistence of nodal solutions is also studied. Additionally, we explore several relations between eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of the p - and q -Laplacians in one dimension.

The potential V is positive and f is a superlinear function of C 1 class. We use Mountain Pass Theorem and the penalization arguments introduced by Del Pino & Felmer‚Äôs associated to Lions‚Äô Concentration and Compactness Principle in order to overcome the lack of compactness.

title: Spectral discretization of the time-dependent Navier-Stokes problem with mixed boundary conditions
abstract: Abstract In this work, we handle a time-dependent Navier-Stokes problem in dimension three with a mixed boundary conditions. The variational formulation is written considering three independent unknowns: vorticity, velocity, and pressure. We use the backward Euler scheme for time discretization and the spectral method for space discretization. We present a complete numerical analysis linked to this variational formulation, which leads us to a priori error estimate.

title: Construction of type I blowup solutions for a higher order semilinear parabolic equation
authors: Tej‚ÄêEddine Ghoul; Van Tien Nguyen; Hatem Zaag
abstract: Abstract We consider the higher-order semilinear parabolic equation $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \partial_t u = -(-{\it\Delta})^{m} u + u|u|^{p-1}, \end{array}$$ in the whole space ‚Ñù N , where p > 1 and m ‚â• 1 is an odd integer. We exhibit type I non self-similar blowup solutions for this equation and obtain a sharp description of its asymptotic behavior. The method of construction relies on the spectral analysis of a non self-adjoint linearized operator in an appropriate scaled variables setting. In view of known spectral and sectorial properties of the linearized operator obtained by Galaktionov [15], we revisit the technique developed by Merle-Zaag [23] for the classical case m = 1, which consists in two steps: the reduction of the problem to a finite dimensional one, then solving the finite dimensional problem by a classical topological argument based on the index theory. Our analysis provides a rigorous justification of a formal result in [15].

title: A Picone identity for variable exponent operators and applications
authors: Rakesh Arora; Jacques Giacomoni; Guillaume Warnault
abstract: Abstract In this work, we establish a new Picone identity for anisotropic quasilinear operators, such as the p ( x )-Laplacian defined as div(|‚àá u | p ( x )‚àí2 ‚àá u ). Our extension provides a new version of the Diaz-Saa inequality and new uniqueness results to some quasilinear elliptic equations with variable exponents. This new Picone identity can be also used to prove some accretivity property to a class of fast diffusion equations involving variable exponents. Using this, we prove for this class of parabolic equations a new weak comparison principle.

title: Sign-changing multi-bump solutions for the Chern-Simons-Schr√∂dinger equations in ‚Ñù2
authors: Zhi Chen; Xianhua Tang; Jian Zhang
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider the nonlinear Chern-Simons-Schr√∂dinger equations with general nonlinearity $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle -{\it\Delta} u+\lambda V(|x|)u+\left(\frac{h^2(|x|)}{|x|^2}+\int\limits^{\infty}_{|x|}\frac{h(s)}{s}u^2(s)ds\right)u=f(u),\,\, x\in\mathbb R^2, \end{array}$$ where Œª > 0, V is an external potential and $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle h(s)=\frac{1}{2}\int\limits^s_0ru^2(r)dr=\frac{1}{4\pi}\int\limits_{B_s}u^2(x)dx \end{array}$$ is the so-called Chern-Simons term. Assuming that the external potential V is nonnegative continuous function with a potential well Œ© := int V ‚Äì1 (0) consisting of k + 1 disjoint components Œ© 0 , Œ© 1 , Œ© 2 ‚ãØ, Œ© k , and the nonlinearity f has a general subcritical growth condition, we are able to establish the existence of sign-changing multi-bump solutions by using variational methods. Moreover, the concentration behavior of solutions as Œª ‚Üí +‚àû are also considered.

title: On hemicontinuity of bifunctions for solving equilibrium problems
abstract: Abstract. This paper deals with solving equilibrium problems under local conditions on equilibrium bifunctions. Some techniques first considered for multivalued mixed variational inequalities are investigated and applied to equilibrium problems. It results that the notion of hemicontinuity is not needed on the whole space when solving equilibrium problems involving pseudomonotone or quasimonotone bifunctions. Generalizations of some well-known results concerning existence of solutions of equilibrium problems are obtained and applications to equilibrium problems involving two, rather than one, bifunctions are given.

title: Multiple nonradial solutions for a nonlinear elliptic problem with singular and decaying radial potential
abstract: Many existence and nonexistence results are known for nonnegative radial solutions $u\in D^{1,2}(\mathbb{R}^{N})\cap L^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{N},\left|x\right| ^{-\alpha }dx)$ to the equation \[ -\triangle u+\dfrac{A}{\left| x\right| ^{\alpha }}u=f\left( u\right) \quad \textrm{in }\mathbb{R}^{N},\quad N\geq 3,\quad A,\alpha >0, \] with nonlinearites satisfying $\left| f\left( u\right) \right| \leq \left(\mathrm{const.}\right) u^{p-1}$ for some $p>2$. Existence of nonradial solutions, by contrast, is known only for $N\geq 4$, $\alpha =2$, $f\left( u\right) =u^{(N+2)/(N-2)}$ and $A$ large enough. Here we show that the equation has multiple nonradial solutions as $A\rightarrow +\infty$ for $N\geq 4$, $2/(N-1)<\alpha <2N-2$, $\alpha\neq 2$, and nonlinearities satisfying suitable assumptions. Our argument essentially relies on the compact embeddings between some suitable functional spaces of symmetric functions, which yields the existence of nonnegative solutions of mountain-pass type, and the separation of the corresponding mountain-pass levels from the energy levels associated to radial solutions.

title: Continuity results for parametric nonlinear singular Dirichlet problems
authors: Yunru Bai; Dumitru Motreanu; Shengda Zeng
abstract: Abstract In this paper we study from a qualitative point of view the nonlinear singular Dirichlet problem depending on a parameter Œª > 0 that was considered in [32]. Denoting by S Œª the set of positive solutions of the problem corresponding to the parameter Œª , we establish the following essential properties of S Œª : there exists a smallest element $\begin{array}{} u_\lambda^* \end{array}$ in S Œª , and the mapping Œª ‚Ü¶ $\begin{array}{} u_\lambda^* \end{array}$ is (strictly) increasing and left continuous; the set-valued mapping Œª ‚Ü¶ S Œª is sequentially continuous.

title: On a logarithmic Hartree equation
abstract: Abstract We study the existence of radially symmetric solutions for a nonlinear planar Schr√∂dinger-Poisson system in presence of a superlinear reaction term which doesn‚Äôt satisfy the Ambrosetti-Rabinowitz condition. The system is re-written as a nonlinear Hartree equation with a logarithmic convolution term, and the existence of a positive and a negative solution is established via critical point theory.

title: Multiplicity and concentration results for magnetic relativistic Schr√∂dinger equations
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the following magnetic pseudo-relativistic Schr√∂dinger equation $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \sqrt{\left(\frac{\varepsilon}{i}\nabla-A(x)\right)^2+m^2}u+V(x)u= f(|u|)u \quad {\rm in}\,\,\mathbb{R}^N, \end{array}$$ where Œµ > 0 is a parameter, m > 0, N ‚â• 1, V : ‚Ñù N ‚Üí ‚Ñù is a continuous scalar potential satisfies V ( x ) ‚â• ‚àí V 0 > ‚àí m for any x ‚àà ‚Ñù N and f : ‚Ñù N ‚Üí ‚Ñù is a continuous function. Under a local condition imposed on the potential V , we discuss the number of nontrivial solutions with the topology of the set where the potential attains its minimum. We proof our results via variational methods, penalization techniques and Ljusternik-Schnirelmann theory.

title: Morrey estimates for a class of elliptic equations with drift term
authors: G. R. Cirmi; S. D‚ÄôAsero; Salvatore Leonardi
abstract: Abstract We consider the following boundary value problem $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \begin{cases} - {\rm div}{[M(x)\nabla u - E(x) u]} =f(x) & \text{in}~~ {\it\Omega} \\ u =0 & \text{on}~~ \partial{\it\Omega}, \end{cases} \end{array}$$ where Œ© is a bounded open subset of ‚Ñù N , with N > 2, M : Œ© ‚Üí ‚Ñù N 2 is a symmetric matrix, E ( x ) and f ( x ) are respectively a vector field and function both belonging to suitable Morrey spaces and we study the corresponding regularity of u and D u .

title: Convergence Results for Elliptic Variational-Hemivariational Inequalities
authors: Dong-ling Cai; Mircea Sofonea; Yi‚Äêbin Xiao
abstract: Abstract We consider an elliptic variational-hemivariational inequality ùìü in a reflexive Banach space, governed by a set of constraints K , a nonlinear operator A , and an element f . We associate to this inequality a sequence {ùìü n } of variational-hemivariational inequalities such that, for each n ‚àà ‚Ñï, inequality ùìü n is obtained by perturbing the data K and A and, moreover, it contains an additional term governed by a small parameter Œµ n . The unique solvability of ùìü and, for each n ‚àà ‚Ñï, the solvability of its perturbed version ùìü n , are guaranteed by an existence and uniqueness result obtained in literature. Denote by u the solution of Problem ùìü and, for each n ‚àà ‚Ñï, let u n be a solution of Problem ùìü n . The main result of this paper states the strong convergence of u n ‚Üí u in X , as n ‚Üí ‚àû. We show that the main result extends a number of results previously obtained in the study of Problem ùìü. Finally, we illustrate the use of our abstract results in the study of a mathematical model which describes the contact of an elastic body with a rigid-deformable foundation and provide the corresponding mechanical interpretations.

title: Analysis of a diffusive host-pathogen model with standard incidence and distinct dispersal rates
abstract: Abstract This paper concerns with detailed analysis of a reaction-diffusion host-pathogen model with space-dependent parameters in a bounded domain. By considering the fact the mobility of host individuals playing a crucial role in disease transmission, we formulate the model by a system of degenerate reaction-diffusion equations, where host individuals disperse at distinct rates and the mobility of pathogen is ignored in the environment.We first establish the well-posedness of the model, including the global existence of solution and the existence of the global compact attractor. The basic reproduction number is identified, and also characterized by some equivalent principal spectral conditions, which establishes the threshold dynamical result for pathogen extinction and persistence. When the positive steady state is confirmed, we investigate the asymptotic profiles of positive steady state as host individuals disperse at small and large rates. Our result suggests that small and large diffusion rate of hosts have a great impacts in formulating the spatial distribution of the pathogen.

title: Local versus nonlocal elliptic equations: short-long range field interactions
authors: Daniele Cassani; Luca Vilasi; Youjun Wang
abstract: Abstract In this paper we study a class of one-parameter family of elliptic equations which combines local and nonlocal operators, namely the Laplacian and the fractional Laplacian. We analyze spectral properties, establish the validity of the maximum principle, prove existence, nonexistence, symmetry and regularity results for weak solutions. The asymptotic behavior of weak solutions as the coupling parameter vanishes (which turns the problem into a purely nonlocal one) or goes to infinity (reducing the problem to the classical semilinear Laplace equation) is also investigated.

u+V(x)u=\left(I_{\alpha}\ast [Q(x)|u|^{\frac{N+\alpha}{N}}]\right)Q(x)|u|^{\frac{\alpha}{N}-1}u, \quad x\in \mathbb R^N. \end{array}$$ By using variational approaches, we investigate the existence of groundstates relying on the asymptotic behaviour of weighted potentials at infinity. Moreover, non-existence of non-trivial solutions is also considered. In particular, we give a partial answer to some open questions raised in [D.~Cassani, J. Van Schaftingen and J. J. Zhang, Groundstates for Choquard type equations with Hardy-Littlewood-Sobolev lower critical exponent, Proceedings of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, Section A Mathematics , 150 (2020), 1377‚Äì1400].

title: Positive solutions for (p, q)-equations with convection and a sign-changing reaction
abstract: Abstract We consider a nonlinear Dirichlet problem driven by the ( p , q )-Laplacian and with a reaction which is dependent on the gradient. We look for positive solutions and we do not assume that the reaction is nonnegative. Using a mixture of variational and topological methods (the "frozen variable" technique), we prove the existence of a positive smooth solution.

title: Gradient estimates for nonlinear elliptic equations involving the Witten Laplacian on smooth metric measure spaces and implications
abstract: Abstract This article presents new local and global gradient estimates of Li-Yau type for positive solutions to a class of nonlinear elliptic equations on smooth metric measure spaces involving the Witten Laplacian. The estimates are derived under natural lower bounds on the associated Bakry-√âmery Ricci curvature tensor and find utility in proving fairly general Harnack inequalities and Liouville-type theorems to name a few. The results here unify, extend and improve various existing results in the literature for special nonlinearities already of huge interest and applications. Some consequences are presented and discussed.

title: Incompressible limit for compressible viscoelastic flows with large velocity
authors: Xianpeng Hu; Yaobin Ou; Dehua Wang; Lu Yang
abstract: Abstract We are concerned with the incompressible limit of global-in-time strong solutions with arbitrary large initial velocity for the three-dimensional compressible viscoelastic equations. The incompressibility is achieved by the large value of the volume viscosity, which is different from the low Mach number limit. To obtain the uniform estimates, we establish the estimates for the potential part and the divergence-free part of the velocity. As the volume viscosity goes to infinity, the dispersion associated with the pressure waves tends to disappear, but the large volume viscosity provides a strong dissipation on the potential part of the velocity forcing the flow to be almost incompressible.

title: The bounded variation capacity and Sobolev-type inequalities on Dirichlet spaces
authors: Xiang-Yun Xie; Yu Liu; Pengtao Li; Jizheng Huang
abstract: Abstract In this article, we consider the bounded variation capacity (BV capacity) and characterize the Sobolev-type inequalities related to BV functions in a general framework of strictly local Dirichlet spaces with a doubling measure via the BV capacity. Under a weak Bakry-√âmery curvature-type condition, we give the connection between the Hausdorff measure and the Hausdorff capacity, and discover some capacitary inequalities and Maz‚Äôya-Sobolev inequalities for BV functions. The De Giorgi characterization for total variation is also obtained with a quasi-Bakry-√âmery curvature condition. It should be noted that the results in this article are proved if the Dirichlet space supports the weak <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left(1,2) -Poincar√© inequality instead of the weak <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left(1,1) -Poincar√© inequality compared with the results in the previous references.

title: Nontrivial solutions for resonance quasilinear elliptic systems
authors: Natalino Borgia; Silvia Cingolani; Giuseppina Vannella
abstract: Abstract We establish an Amann-Zehnder-type result for resonance systems of quasilinear elliptic equations with homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions, involving nonlinearities growing asymptotically <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left(p,q) -linear at infinity. The proof relies on a cohomological linking in a product Banach space where the properties of cones of the sublevels are missing, differently from the single quasilinear equation. We also perform critical group computations of the energy functional at the origin, in spite of the lack of its <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{2} regularity, to exclude that the found mini-max solution is trivial. Finally, we furnish a local condition which guarantees that the found solution is not semi-trivial.

title: Boussinesq's equation for water waves: Asymptotics in Sector I
abstract: Abstract In a recent study, we showed that the large <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left(x,t) behavior of a class of physically relevant solutions of Boussinesq‚Äôs equation for water waves is described by ten main asymptotic sectors. In the sector adjacent to the positive <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:math> x -axis, referred to as Sector I, we stated without proof an exact expression for the leading asymptotic term together with an error estimate. Here, we provide a proof of this asymptotic formula.

title: Existence and multiplicity of solutions for a new p(x)-Kirchhoff equation
abstract: Abstract This article is devoted to study a class of new <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(x) -Kirchhoff equation. By means of perturbation technique, variational method, and the method invariant sets for the descending flow, the existence and multiplicity of solutions to this problem are obtained.

This particular quasilinear term generally appears in the study of nonlinear optics model, which describes the propagation of self-trapped beam in a cylindrical optical fiber made from a self-focusing dielectric material. When the reaction term is concave-convex nonlinearities, by using the Nehari manifold and doing a fine analysis associated on the fibering map, we obtain that the equation admits at least one positive energy solution and negative energy solution, which is also the ground state solution of the equation. We overcome two main difficulties which are caused by the nonhomogeneity of the differential operator <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>S</m:mi> </m:math> S : (i) the almost everywhere convergence of the gradient for the minimizing sequence <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>{</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:mrow> <m:mo>}</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left\{{u}_{n}ight\} ; (ii) seeking the reasonable restrictions about <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>S</m:mi> </m:math> S .

title: On the positive, ‚Äúradial‚Äù solutions of a semilinear elliptic equation in N $\mathbb {H}^N$
abstract: We discuss various kinds of existence and non existence results for positive solutions of Emden‚ÄìFowler type equations in the hyperbolic space. The main tools are perturbation analysis, variational methods, Pohozeav type identities and reduction to Matukuma equations.

title: (p,2)-equations asymmetric at both zero and infinity
authors: ŒùŒπŒ∫œåŒªŒ±ŒøœÇ Œ†Œ±œÄŒ±Œ≥ŒµœâœÅŒ≥ŒØŒøœÖ; Vicen≈£iu D. RƒÉdulescu; Du≈°an Repov≈°
abstract: We consider a $(p,2)$-equation, that is, a nonlinear nonhomogeneous elliptic equation driven by the sum of a $p$-Laplacian and a Laplacian with $p>2$. The reaction term is $(p-1)$-linear but exhibits asymmetric behaviour at $\pm\infty$ and at $0^{\pm}$. Using variational tools, together with truncation and comparison techniques and Morse theory, we prove two multiplicity theorems, one of them providing sign information for all the solutions (positive, negative, nodal).

title: Nonlinear Sherman-type inequalities
abstract: Abstract An important class of Schur-convex functions is generated by convex functions via the well-known Hardy‚ÄìLittlewood‚ÄìP√≥lya‚ÄìKaramata inequality. Sherman‚Äôs inequality is a natural generalization of the HLPK inequality. It can be viewed as a comparison of two special inner product expressions induced by a convex function of one variable. In the present note, we extend the Sherman inequality from the (bilinear) inner product to a (nonlinear) map of two vectorial variables satisfying the Leon‚ÄìProschan condition. Some applications are shown for directional derivatives and gradients of Schur-convex functions.

title: Higher-order anisotropic models in phase separation
authors: Laurence Cherfils; Alain Miranville; Shuiran Peng
abstract: Abstract Our aim in this paper is to study higher-order (in space) Allen‚ÄìCahn and Cahn‚ÄìHilliard models. In particular, we obtain well-posedness results, as well as the existence of the global attractor. We also give, for the Allen‚ÄìCahn models, numerical simulations which illustrate the effects of the higher-order terms and the anisotropy.

title: A class of semipositonep-Laplacian problems with a critical growth reaction term
authors: Kanishka Perera; R. Shivaji; Inbo Sim
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of ground state positive solutions for a class of semipositone p -Laplacian problems with a critical growth reaction term. The proofs are established by obtaining crucial uniform C 1, Œ± a priori estimates and by concentration compactness arguments. Our results are new even in the semilinear case p = 2.

title: Homogenization of a net of periodic critically scaled boundary obstacles related to reverse osmosis ‚Äúnano-composite‚Äù membranes
authors: Jes√∫s Ildefonso D√≠az D√≠az; David G√≥mez‚ÄêCastro; Alexander Podolskiy; –¢. –ê. –®–∞–ø–æ—à–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤–∞
abstract: Abstract One of the main goals of this paper is to extend some of the mathematical techniques of some previous papers by the authors showing that some very useful phenomenological properties which can be observed at the nano-scale can be simulated and justified mathematically by means of some homogenization processes when a certain critical scale is used in the corresponding framework. Here the motivating problem in consideration is formulated in the context of the reverse osmosis. We consider, on a part of the boundary of a domain <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}} , a set of very small periodically distributed semipermeable membranes having an ideal infinite permeability coefficient (which leads to Signorini-type boundary conditions) on a part <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œì</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:math> {\Gamma_{1}} of the boundary. We also assume that a possible chemical reaction may take place on the membranes. We obtain the rigorous convergence of the problems to a homogenized problem in which there is a change in the constitutive nonlinearities. Changes of this type are the reason for the big success of the nanocomposite materials. Our proof is carried out for membranes not necessarily of radially symmetric shape. The definition of the associated critical scale depends on the dimension of the space (and it is quite peculiar for the special case of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {n=2} ). Roughly speaking, our result proves that the consideration of the critical case of the scale leads to a homogenized formulation which is equivalent to having a global semipermeable membrane, at the whole part of the boundary <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œì</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:math> {\Gamma_{1}} , with a ‚Äúfinite permeability coefficient of this virtual membrane‚Äù, which is the best we can get, even if the original problem involves a set of membranes of any arbitrary finite permeability coefficients.

title: Existence of standing waves for quasi-linear Schr√∂dinger equations on T n
abstract: Abstract This paper is devoted to the study of the existence of standing waves for a class of quasi-linear Schr√∂dinger equations on T n with dimension n ‚â• 3. By construction of a suitable Nash-Moser-type iteration scheme, we overcome the clusters of ‚Äúsmall divisor‚Äù problem, then the existence of standing waves for quasi-linear Schr√∂dinger equations is established.

title: Periodic traveling fronts for partially degenerate reaction-diffusion systems with bistable and time-periodic nonlinearity
abstract: Abstract This paper is concerned with the periodic traveling fronts for partially degenerate reaction-diffusion systems with bistable and time-periodic nonlinearity. We first determine the signs of wave speeds for two monostable periodic traveling fronts of the system. Then, we prove the existence of periodic traveling fronts connecting two stable periodic solutions. An estimate of the wave speed is also obtained. Further, we prove the monotonicity, uniqueness (up to a translation), Liapunov stability and exponentially asymptotical stability of the smooth bistable periodic traveling fronts.

title: Eigenvalues for a class of singular problems involving p(x)-Biharmonic operator and q(x)-Hardy potential
authors: Abdelouahed El Khalil; Mohamed Laghzal; My Driss Morchid Alaoui; Abdelfattah Touzani
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the nonlinear eigenvalue problem: $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \begin{cases} {\it\Delta}(|{\it\Delta} u|^{p(x)-2}{\it\Delta} u)= \lambda \frac{|u|^{q(x)-2}u}{{\delta(x)}^{2q(x)}} \;\; \mbox{in}\;\; {\it\Omega}, \\ u\in W_0^{2,p(x)}({\it\Omega}), \end{cases} \end{array}$$ where Œ© is a regular bounded domain of ‚Ñù N , Œ¥ ( x ) = dist ( x , ‚àÇŒ© ) the distance function from the boundary ‚àÇŒ© , Œª is a positive real number, and functions p (‚ãÖ), q (‚ãÖ) are supposed to be continuous on Œ© satisfying $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle 1 \lt \min_{\overline{{\it\Omega} }}\,q\leq \max_{\overline{{\it\Omega}}}\,q \lt \min_{\overline{{\it\Omega} }}\,p \leq \max_{\overline{{\it\Omega}}}\,p \lt \frac{N}{2} \mbox{ and } \max_{\overline{{\it\Omega}}}\,q \lt p_2^*:= \frac{Np(x)}{N-2p(x)} \end{array}$$ for any x ‚àà Œ© . We prove the existence of at least one non-decreasing sequence of positive eigenvalues. Moreover, we prove that sup Œõ = +‚àû, where Œõ is the spectrum of the problem. Furthermore, we give a proof of positivity of inf Œõ > 0 provided that Hardy-Rellich inequality holds.

title: Existence of positive periodic solutions for fourth-order nonlinear neutral differential equations with variable delay
authors: Abdelouaheb Ardjouni; Ali Rezaiguia; Ahc√©ne Djoudi
abstract: Abstract. In this article we study the existence of positive periodic solutions for a fourth-order nonlinear neutral differential equation with variable delay. The main tool employed here is the Krasnoselskii's fixed point theorem dealing with a sum of two mappings, one is a contraction and the other one is completely continuous.

title: Nontrivial solutions for singular semilinear elliptic equations on the Heisenberg group
abstract: Abstract. We employ Bonanno's three critical point theorem to obtain the existence of weak solutions.

title: Maximum principles, Liouville-type theorems and symmetry results for a general class of quasilinear anisotropic equations
abstract: Abstract This paper is concerned with a general class of quasilinear anisotropic equations. We first derive some maximum principles for two appropriate P -functions, in the sense of Payne (see the book of Sperb [18]). These maximum principles are then employed to obtain a Liouville-type result and a Serrin‚ÄìWeinberger-type symmetry result.

title: Global well-posedness of some high-order focusing semilinear evolution equations with exponential nonlinearity
abstract: Abstract In even space dimensions, the initial value problems for some high-order focusing semilinear evolution equations with exponential nonlinearities are considered. Using the potential well method, global and nonglobal well-posedness in the energy space are obtained.

title: Well-posedness and maximum principles for lattice reaction-diffusion equations
authors: Anton√≠n Slav√≠k; Petr Stehl√≠k; Jon√°≈° Volek
abstract: Abstract Existence, uniqueness and continuous dependence results together with maximum principles represent key tools in the analysis of lattice reaction-diffusion equations. In this paper, we study these questions in full generality by considering nonautonomous reaction functions, possibly nonsymmetric diffusion and continuous, discrete or mixed time. First, we prove the local existence and global uniqueness of bounded solutions, as well as the continuous dependence of solutions on the underlying time structure and on initial conditions. Next, we obtain the weak maximum principle which enables us to get the global existence of solutions. Finally, we provide the strong maximum principle which exhibits an interesting dependence on the time structure. Our results are illustrated by the autonomous Fisher and Nagumo lattice equations and a nonautonomous logistic population model with a variable carrying capacity.

title: Lichnerowicz-type equations on complete manifolds
abstract: Abstract Under appropriate spectral assumptions, we prove two existence results for positive solutions of Lichnerowicz-type equations on complete manifolds. We also give a priori bounds and a comparison result that immediately yields uniqueness for certain classes of solutions. No curvature assumptions are involved in our analysis.

title: On the exact multiplicity of stable ground states of non-Lipschitz semilinear elliptic equations for some classes of starshaped sets
authors: Jes√∫s Ildefonso D√≠az D√≠az; Jes√∫s Hern√°ndez; Y.Sh. Ilyasov
abstract: Abstract We prove the exact multiplicity of flat and compact support stable solutions of an autonomous non-Lipschitz semilinear elliptic equation of eigenvalue type according to the dimension N and the two exponents, 0 < Œ± < Œ≤ < 1, of the involved nonlinearites. Suitable assumptions are made on the spatial domain Œ© where the problem is formulated in order to avoid a possible continuum of those solutions and, on the contrary, to ensure the exact number of solutions according to the nature of the domain Œ© . Our results also clarify some previous works in the literature. The main techniques of proof are a Pohozhaev‚Äôs type identity and some fibering type arguments in the variational approach.

title: On the existence of periodic oscillations for pendulum-type equations
abstract: Abstract We provide new sufficient conditions for the existence of T -periodic solutions for the œï -laplacian pendulum equation ( œï ( x ‚Ä≤))‚Ä≤ + k x ‚Ä≤ + a sin x = e ( t ), where e ‚àà CÕ† T . Our main tool is a continuation theorem due to Capietto, Mawhin and Zanolin and we improve or complement previous results in the literature obtained in the framework of the classical, the relativistic and the curvature pendulum equations.

L^{\infty }(\mathbb {R},\mathbb {R})}$ can change its sign and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${0&lt;p&lt;1}$ is a constant, we show that the above fractional Hamiltonian systems possess infinitely-many solutions. The proof is based on the symmetric mountain pass theorem. Recent results in the literature are generalized and significantly improved.

title: Multivalued problem with Robin boundary condition involving diffuse measure data and variable exponent
authors: Stanislas Ouaro; Arouna Ou√©draogo; Safimba Soma
abstract: Abstract We study a nonlinear elliptic problem with Robin type boundary condition, governed by a general Leray‚ÄìLions operator with variable exponents and diffuse Radon measure data which does not charge the sets of zero p (¬∑)-capacity. We prove an existence and uniqueness result of a weak solution.

title: A trace problem for associate Morrey potentials
abstract: Abstract As a solution to the restriction question for associate Morrey potentials (Question 1.1), this paper characterizes a Radon measure Œº on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{n}} such that the Riesz operator <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>I</m:mi> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> </m:msub> </m:math> {I_{\alpha}} maps the associate Morrey spaces <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>H</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>H</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {H^{p,\kappa}_{1}\subset H^{p,\kappa}} to the Œº-induced Morrey spaces <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {L^{q,\lambda}_{\mu}\subset L^{q,\lambda}_{\mu,\infty}} continuously. The discovered restriction/trace principle (Theorem 1.2) is brand-new, and its demonstration is non-trivial.

title: Singular limit solutions for a 2-dimensional semilinear elliptic system of Liouville type
abstract: Abstract We consider the existence of singular limit solutions for a nonlinear elliptic system of Liouville type with Dirichlet boundary conditions. We use the nonlinear domain decomposition method.

title: Coercive elliptic systems with gradient terms
abstract: Abstract In this paper we give a classification of positive radial solutions of the following system: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>Œî</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:msup><m:mi>v</m:mi><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:msup></m:mrow><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>Œî</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>v</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>h</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>|</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo>|</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>g</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>f</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>|</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>‚àá</m:mo><m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>|</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo>,</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> $\Delta u=v^{m},\quad\Delta v=h(|x|)g(u)f(|\nabla u|),$ in the open ball <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msub><m:mi>B</m:mi><m:mi>R</m:mi></m:msub></m:math> ${B_{R}}$ , with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi><m:mo>></m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn></m:mrow></m:math> ${m>0}$ , and f , g , h nonnegative nondecreasing continuous functions. In particular, we deal with both explosive and bounded solutions. Our results involve, as in [27], a generalization of the well-known Keller‚ÄìOsserman condition, namely, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:msubsup><m:mo>‚à´</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn><m:mi>‚àû</m:mi></m:msubsup><m:mrow><m:mpadded><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msubsup><m:mo>‚à´</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mi>s</m:mi></m:msubsup><m:mrow><m:mi>F</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>ùëë</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mo>-</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi><m:mo>/</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mn>2</m:mn><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:msup></m:mpadded><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>ùëë</m:mo><m:mi>s</m:mi></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo><</m:mo><m:mi>‚àû</m:mi></m:mrow></m:math> ${\int_{1}^{\infty}(\int_{0}^{s}F(t)\,dt)^{-m/(2m+1)}\,ds<\infty}$ , where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>F</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msubsup><m:mo>‚à´</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mi>t</m:mi></m:msubsup><m:mrow><m:mi>f</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mi>s</m:mi><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>ùëë</m:mo><m:mi>s</m:mi></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:math> ${F(t)=\int_{0}^{t}f(s)\,ds}$ . Moreover, in the second part of the paper, the p -Laplacian version, given by <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:msub><m:mi>Œî</m:mi><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:msub><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:msup><m:mi>v</m:mi><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:msup></m:mrow></m:math> ${\Delta_{p}u=v^{m}}$ , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:msub><m:mi>Œî</m:mi><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:msub><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>v</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>f</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>|</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>‚àá</m:mo><m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>|</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:math> ${\Delta_{p}v=f(|\nabla u|)}$ , is treated. When <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mi>p</m:mi><m:mo>‚â•</m:mo><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow></m:math> ${p\geq 2}$ , we prove a necessary condition for the existence of a solution with at least a blow up component at the boundary, precisely <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:msubsup><m:mo>‚à´</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn><m:mi>‚àû</m:mi></m:msubsup><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msubsup><m:mo>‚à´</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mi>s</m:mi></m:msubsup><m:mrow><m:mi>F</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>ùëë</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mo>-</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi><m:mo>/</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>-</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:msup><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mpadded><m:msup><m:mi>s</m:mi><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>p</m:mi><m:mo>-</m:mo><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>p</m:mi><m:mo>-</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo>/</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>-</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:msup></m:mpadded><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>ùëë</m:mo><m:mi>s</m:mi></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mo><</m:mo><m:mi>‚àû</m:mi></m:mrow></m:math> ${\int_{1}^{\infty}(\int_{0}^{s}F(t)\,dt)^{-m/(mp+p-1)}s^{(p-2)(p-1)/(mp+p-1)}% \,ds<\infty}$ .

title: On nonlinear potential theory, and regular boundary points, for the p-Laplacian in N space variables
abstract: Abstract. We turn back to some pioneering results concerning, in particular, nonlinear potential theory and non-homogeneous boundary value problems for the so-called p -Laplace operator. Unfortunately these results, obtained at the very beginning of the seventies, were kept in the shade. We believe that our proofs are still of interest, in particular due to their extreme simplicity. Moreover, some contributions seem to improve the results quoted in the current literature.

title: Iterative methods for monotone nonexpansive mappings in uniformly convex spaces
abstract: Abstract We show the nonlinear ergodic theorem for monotone 1-Lipschitz mappings in uniformly convex spaces: if C is a bounded closed convex subset of an ordered uniformly convex space ( X , ‚à£¬∑‚à£, ‚™Ø), T : C ‚Üí C a monotone 1-Lipschitz mapping and x ‚™Ø T ( x ), then the sequence of averages <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mfrac> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mo movablelimits="false">‚àë</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>T</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:math> $ \frac{1}{n}\sum\nolimits_{i=0}^{n-1}T^{i}(x) $ converges weakly to a fixed point of T . As a consequence, it is shown that the sequence of Picard‚Äôs iteration { T n ( x )} also converges weakly to a fixed point of T . The results are new even in a Hilbert space. The Krasnosel‚Äôskiƒ≠-Mann and the Halpern iteration schemes are studied as well.

title: Anomalous pseudo-parabolic Kirchhoff-type dynamical model
authors: Xiaoqiang Dai; Jiangbo Han; Qiang Lin; Xueteng Tian
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study an anomalous pseudo-parabolic Kirchhoff-type dynamical model aiming to reveal the control problem of the initial data on the dynamical behavior of the solution in dynamic control system. Firstly, the local existence of solution is obtained by employing the Contraction Mapping Principle. Then, we get the global existence of solution, long time behavior of global solution and blowup solution for J ( u 0 ) ‚©Ω d , respectively. In particular, the lower and upper bound estimates of the blowup time are given for J ( u 0 )< d . Finally, we discuss the blowup of solution in finite time and also estimate an upper bound of the blowup time for high initial energy.

title: A regularized gradient flow for the p-elastic energy
authors: Simon Blatt; Christopher Hopper; Nicole Vorderobermeier
abstract: Abstract We prove long-time existence for the negative <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {L}^{2} -gradient flow of the p -elastic energy, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> p\ge 2 , with an additive positive multiple of the length of the curve. To achieve this result, we regularize the energy by cutting off the degeneracy at points with vanishing curvature and add a small multiple of a higher order energy, namely, the square of the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {L}^{2} -norm of the normal gradient of the curvature <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi> </m:math> \kappa . Long-time existence is proved for the gradient flow of these new energies together with the smooth subconvergence of the evolution equation‚Äôs solutions to critical points of the regularized energy in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {W}^{2,p} . We then show that the solutions to the regularized evolution equations converge to a weak solution of the negative gradient flow of the p -elastic energies. These latter weak solutions also subconverge to critical points of the p -elastic energy.

title: Bifurcation diagrams of one-dimensional Kirchhoff-type equations
abstract: Abstract We study the one-dimensional Kirchhoff-type equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mo form="prefix">‚àí</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> {\left(x)}^{2}{\rm{d}}x\right)}^{1\text{/}2} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>a</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>b</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> \lambda \gt 0 is a bifurcation parameter. We establish the exact solution <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {u}_{\lambda }\left(x) and complete shape of the bifurcation curves <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œæ</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \lambda =\lambda \left(\xi ) , where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œæ</m:mi> <m:mo>‚âî</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Äñ</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Äñ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> \xi := \Vert {u}_{\lambda }{\Vert }_{\infty } . We also study the nonlinear eigenvalue problem <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mo>‚Äñ</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo accent="false">‚Ä≤</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Äñ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo accent="true">‚Ä≥</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mi>I</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1em" /> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mi>I</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1em" /> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>¬±</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:math> -\Vert u^{\prime} {\Vert }^{p-1}{u}^{^{\prime\prime} }\left(x)=\mu u{\left(x)}^{p},x\in I,\hspace{1em}u\left(x)\gt 0,x\in I,\hspace{1em}u\left(\pm 1)=0, where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> p\gt 1 is a given constant and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œº</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> \mu \gt 0 is an eigenvalue parameter. We obtain the first eigenvalue and eigenfunction of this problem explicitly by using a simple time map method.

title: Solutions for nonhomogeneous fractional (p,q)-Laplacian systems with critical nonlinearities
abstract: Abstract In this article, we aimed to study a class of nonhomogeneous fractional ( p , q )-Laplacian systems with critical nonlinearities as well as critical Hardy nonlinearities in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup></m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{N} . By appealing to a fixed point result and fractional Hardy-Sobolev inequality, the existence of nontrivial nonnegative solutions is obtained. In particular, we also consider Choquard-type nonlinearities in the second part of this article. More precisely, with the help of Hardy-Littlewood-Sobolev inequality, we obtain the existence of nontrivial solutions for the related systems based on the same approach. Finally, we obtain the corresponding existence results for the fractional ( p , q )-Laplacian systems in the case of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>N</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mi>s</m:mi><m:mi>p</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mi>l</m:mi><m:mi>q</m:mi></m:math> N=sp=lq . It is worth pointing out that using fixed point argument to seek solutions for a class of nonhomogeneous fractional ( p , q )-Laplacian systems is the main novelty of this article.

title: Global attractors of the degenerate fractional Kirchhoff wave equation with structural damping or strong damping
abstract: Abstract This article deals with the degenerate fractional Kirchhoff wave equation with structural damping or strong damping. The well-posedness and the existence of global attractor in the natural energy space by virtue of the Faedo-Galerkin method and energy estimates are proved. It is worth mentioning that the results of this article cover the case of possible degeneration (or even negativity) of the stiffness coefficient. Moreover, under further suitable assumptions, the fractal dimension of the global attractor is shown to be infinite by using <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">Z</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {{\mathbb{Z}}}_{2} index theory.

title: Well-posedness and blow-up results for a class of nonlinear fractional Rayleigh-Stokes problem
authors: Jing Na Wang; Ahmed Alsaedi; Bashir Ahmad; Yong Zhou
abstract: Abstract In this article, we consider the fractional Rayleigh-Stokes problem with the nonlinearity term satisfies certain critical conditions. The local existence, uniqueness and continuous dependence upon the initial data of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> </m:math> \varepsilon -regular mild solutions are obtained. Furthermore, a unique continuation result and a blow-up alternative result of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> </m:math> \varepsilon -regular mild solutions are given in the end.

title: Asymptotic proximity to higher order nonlinear differential equations
authors: –ò.–í. –ê—Å—Ç–∞—à–æ–≤–∞; Miroslav Bartu≈°ek; Zuzana Do≈°l√°; Mauro Marini
abstract: Abstract The existence of unbounded solutions and their asymptotic behavior is studied for higher order differential equations considered as perturbations of certain linear differential equations. In particular, the existence of solutions with polynomial-like or noninteger power-law asymptotic behavior is proved. These results give a relation between solutions to nonlinear and corresponding linear equations, which can be interpreted, roughly speaking, as an asymptotic proximity between the linear case and the nonlinear one. Our approach is based on the induction method, an iterative process and suitable estimates for solutions to the linear equation.

title: On multiplicity of solutions to nonlinear Dirac equation with local super-quadratic growth
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study the following nonlinear Dirac equation: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi>i</m:mi> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> <m:mspace width="0.33em"/> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> <m:mspace width="0.33em"/> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àá</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>a</m:mi> <m:mi>Œ≤</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>V</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1em"/> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>.</m:mo> </m:math> -i\alpha \hspace{0.33em}\cdot \hspace{0.33em}\nabla u+a\beta u+V\left(x)u=g\left(x,| u| )u,\hspace{1em}x\in {{\mathbb{R}}}^{3}. The Dirac operator is unbounded from below and above so the associated energy functional is strongly indefinite. Compared with some existing issues, the most interesting problem in this article is that we assume that the nonlinearity satisfies a local super-quadratic growth condition, which is weaker than the usual global version. This case allows the nonlinearity to be super-quadratic at some domains and asymptotically quadratic at other domains. Using variational tools together with deformation lemma, genus theory, and some special techniques, we prove the existence of ground-state solutions and infinitely many geometrically distinct solutions under local super-quadratic growth condition. Our results complement and extend the related results of Bartsch and Ding [ Solutions of nonlinear Dirac equations , J. Differ. Equ. 226 (2006), 210‚Äì249] and of Chen et al. [ Ground state solutions for the Dirac equation with periodic external force field , Sci. Sin. Math. (Chinese) 54 (2024), 747‚Äì764].

title: Combinatorial pth Calabi flows for total geodesic curvatures in spherical background geometry
authors: Bin Liu; Lishan Li; Yi Qi
abstract: Abstract The concept of combinatorial p th Calabi flow is proposed for finding circle packing metrics with prescribed curvatures. It has been studied under the Euclidean and hyperbolic background geometries. This study investigates the combinatorial p th Calabi flow for total geodesic curvatures under the spherical background geometry. It is established that the combinatorial p th Calabi flow, subject to given total geodesic curvatures under the spherical background geometry, exists for all time <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>[</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> t\in \left[0,+\infty ) and converges to an ideal circle pattern metric. This finding introduces a new algorithm for constructing ideal circle pattern metrics with prescribed total geodesic curvatures.

title: Positive solutions for asymptotically linear Schr√∂dinger equation on hyperbolic space
authors: Dongmei Gao; Jun Wang; Zhengping Wang
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study the following stationary Schr√∂dinger equation on hyperbolic space: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1em"/> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>3</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:math> -{\Delta }_{{{\mathbb{H}}}^{N}}u+\lambda u=f\left(u),\hspace{1.0em}x\in {{\mathbb{H}}}^{N},\hspace{1em}N\ge 3, where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {\Delta }_{{{\mathbb{H}}}^{N}} denotes the Laplace-Beltrami operator on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\mathbb{H}}}^{N} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:math> \lambda \in {\mathbb{R}} , and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>f</m:mi> </m:math> f is locally Lipschitz continuous satisfying asymptotically linear at infinity. After a reduction from hyperbolic case to Euclidean case, using variational methods, we prove the existence of positive solutions for the aforementioned equation under suitable conditions on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:math> \lambda and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>f</m:mi> </m:math> f .

Subsequently, the local Pohozaev identity techniques are applied to establish the non-degeneracy of such normalized solutions. This study successfully addresses the complexities arising from the non-local characteristics of the fractional Laplacian in the local analysis and pointwise estimates of solutions. In contrast to the unconstrained scenario, the mass-critical power, denoted as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mn>4</m:mn> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> p=\frac{4s}{N}+1 , acts as a pivotal threshold. It delineates distinct ranges of values for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:math> p , each corresponding to vastly different concentration behaviors exhibited by the solutions. This phenomenon unequivocally underscores the profound impact of constraint conditions on the intricate dynamics of the solutions.

title: Geometric characterization of generalized Haj≈Çasz-Sobolev embedding domains
authors: Ziwei Li; Dachun Yang; Wen Yuan
abstract: Abstract In this article, the authors study the embedding properties of Haj≈Çasz-Sobolev spaces with generalized smoothness on Euclidean domains, whose regularity is described via a smoothness weight function <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> <m:mo>:</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>[</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>[</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \phi :\left[0,\infty )\to \left[0,\infty ) . Given any bounded domain with the slice property, the authors prove that it is a generalized Haj≈Çasz-Sobolev embedding domain if and only if it is a generalized <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>F</m:mi> </m:math> F -weak cigar domain, where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>F</m:mi> </m:math> F is a modulus of continuity related to the weight function <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> </m:math> \phi of the generalized Haj≈Çasz-Sobolev spaces under consideration. Comparing with the classical Haj≈Çasz-Soblev spaces, one main difficulty in dealing with generalized Haj≈Çasz-Sobolev spaces lies in that both its smoothness weight function <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> </m:math> \phi and the related modulus of continuity <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>F</m:mi> </m:math> F have no explicit expression. To overcome this, the authors introduce and use some key indices to accurately describe the increasing or the decreasing behavior of both <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> </m:math> \phi and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>F</m:mi> </m:math> F . Besides the classical Haj≈Çasz-Sobolev spaces, this result can be applied to many other nontrivial spaces such as Haj≈Çasz-Sobolev spaces with logarithmic smoothness and is of wide generality.

title: Subharmonic solutions of first-order Hamiltonian systems

A: Theory Methods]. title: Uniform boundedness and compactness for the commutator of an extension of Riesz transform on stratified Lie groups

title: Bifurcation and multiplicity results for critical problems involving the p-Grushin operator
authors: Paolo Malanchini; Giovanni Molica Bisci; Simone Secchi
abstract: Abstract In this article, we prove a bifurcation and multiplicity result for a critical problem involving a degenerate nonlinear operator <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:math> {\Delta }_{\gamma }^{p} . We extend to a generic <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> p\gt 1 a result, which was proved only when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> p=2 . When <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â†</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> p\ne 2 , the nonlinear operator <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:math> -{\Delta }_{\gamma }^{p} has no linear eigenspaces, so our extension is nontrivial and requires an abstract critical theorem, which is not based on linear subspaces. We use an abstract result based on a pseudo-index related to the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">Z</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {{\mathbb{Z}}}_{2} -cohomological index that is applicable here. We provide a version of the Lions‚Äô concentration-compactness principle for our operator.
