We also apply these results to show the existence of positive radial solutions for high-dimensional generalized double phase problems on the exterior of a ball.

title: A class of hyperbolic variational‚Äìhemivariational inequalities without damping terms
authors: Shengda Zeng; Stanis≈Çaw Mig√≥rski; Van Thien Nguyen
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study a large class of evolutionary variational‚Äìhemivariational inequalities of hyperbolic type without damping terms, in which the functional framework is considered in an evolution triple of spaces. The inequalities contain both a convex potential and a locally Lipschitz superpotential. The results on existence, uniqueness, and regularity of solution to the inequality problem are provided through the Rothe method.

title: Brake orbits for Hamiltonian systems of the classical type via geodesics in singular Finsler metrics
abstract: Abstract We consider Hamiltonian functions of the classical type, namely, even and convex with respect to the generalized momenta. A brake orbit is a periodic solution of Hamilton‚Äôs equations such that the generalized momenta are zero on two different points. Under mild assumptions, this paper reduces the multiplicity problem of the brake orbits for a Hamiltonian function of the classical type to the multiplicity problem of orthogonal geodesic chords in a concave Finslerian manifold with boundary. This paper will be used for a generalization of a Seifert‚Äôs conjecture about the multiplicity of brake orbits to Hamiltonian functions of the classical type.

title: On the solutions to p-Poisson equation with Robin boundary conditions when p goes to +‚àû
authors: Vincenzo Amato; Alba Lia Masiello; Carlo Nitsch; Cristina Trombetti
abstract: Abstract We study the behaviour, when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:math> p\to +\infty , of the first p -Laplacian eigenvalues with Robin boundary conditions and the limit of the associated eigenfunctions. We prove that the limit of the eigenfunctions is a viscosity solution to an eigenvalue problem for the so-called <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:math> \infty -Laplacian. Moreover, in the second part of the article, we focus our attention on the p -Poisson equation when the datum <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>f</m:mi> </m:math> f belongs to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {L}^{\infty }\left(\Omega ) and we study the behaviour of solutions when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:math> p\to \infty .

title: Singularity for a nonlinear degenerate hyperbolic-parabolic coupled system arising from nematic liquid crystals
abstract: Abstract This article focuses on the singularity formation of smooth solutions for a one-dimensional nonlinear degenerate hyperbolic-parabolic coupled system originating from the Poiseuille flow of nematic liquid crystals. Without assuming that the wave speed of the hyperbolic equation is a positive function, we show that its smooth solution will break down in finite time even for an arbitrarily small initial energy. Based on an estimate of the solution for the heat equation, we use the method of characteristics to control the wave speed and its derivative so that the wave speed does not degenerate and its derivative does not change sign in a period of time.

title: Periodic and quasi-periodic solutions of a four-dimensional singular differential system describing the motion of vortices
authors: Zaitao Liang; Shengjun Li; Xin Li
abstract: Abstract In this article, we consider a four-dimensional singular differential system that can describe the dynamics of configurations bearing a small number of vortices in atomic Bose-Einstein condensates. On the basis of the topological degree theory and some analysis methods, we prove that such a system has two distinct families of periodic solutions and two distinct families of quasi-periodic solutions. Some results in the literature are generalized and improved.

Particularly, we obtain the optimal decay bound for initial value <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>v</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {v}_{0} .

title: Modeling Wolbachia infection frequency in mosquito populations via a continuous periodic switching model
abstract: Abstract In this article, we develop a continuous periodic switching model depicting Wolbachia infection frequency dynamics in mosquito populations by releasing Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes, which is different from the discrete modeling efforts in the literature. We obtain sufficient conditions on the existence of a unique and exactly two periodic solutions and analyze the stability of each periodic solution, respectively. We also provide a brief discussion and several numerical examples to illustrate our theoretical results.

title: Periodic solutions to a class of distributed delay differential equations via variational methods
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study the existence of periodic solutions to a class of distributed delay differential equations. We transform the search for periodic solutions with the special symmetry of a delay differential equation to the problem of finding periodic solutions of an associated Hamiltonian system. Using the critical point theory and the pseudo-index theory, we obtain some sufficient conditions for the multiplicity of periodic solutions. This is the first time that critical point theory has been used to study the existence of periodic solutions to distributed delay differential equations.

title: Existence of nontrivial solutions for the Klein-Gordon-Maxwell system with Berestycki-Lions conditions
authors: Xiaoqi Liu; Gui‚ÄêDong Li; Chun‚ÄêLei Tang
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study the following Klein-Gordon-Maxwell system: <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mfenced open="{" close=""> <m:mrow> <m:mspace depth="1.25em"/> <m:mtable displaystyle="true"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">in</m:mi> <m:mspace width="1em"/> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> <m:mtr> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">in</m:mi> <m:mspace width="1em"/> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> </m:math> \left\{\phantom{\rule[-1.25em]{}{0ex}}\begin{array}{l}-\Delta u-\left(2\omega +\phi )\phi u=g\left(u),\hspace{1.0em}{\rm{in}}\hspace{1em}{{\mathbb{R}}}^{3},\hspace{1.0em}\\ \Delta \phi =\left(\omega +\phi ){u}^{2},\hspace{1.0em}{\rm{in}}\hspace{1em}{{\mathbb{R}}}^{3},\hspace{1.0em}\end{array}\right. where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> </m:math> \omega is a constant that stands for the phase; <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:math> u and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>œï</m:mi> </m:math> \phi are unknowns and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>g</m:mi> </m:math> g satisfies the Berestycki-Lions condition [ Nonlinear scalar field equations. I. Existence of a ground state , Arch. Rational Mech. Anal. 82 (1983), 313‚Äì345; Nonlinear scalar field equations. II. Existence of infinitelymany solutions , Arch. Rational Mech. Anal. 82 (1983), 347‚Äì375]. The Klein-Gordon-Maxwell system is a model describing solitary waves for the nonlinear Klein-Gordon equation interacting with an electromagnetic field. By using variational methods and some analysis techniques, the existence of positive solution and multiple solutions can be obtained. Moreover, we study the properties of decay estimates and asymptotic behavior for the positive solution.

title: Generalized Liouville theorem for viscosity solutions to a singular Monge-Amp√®re equation
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study the asymptotic behaviour at infinity for viscosity solutions to a singular Monge-Amp√®re equation in half space from affine geometry. In particular, we extend the Liouville theorem for smooth solutions to the case of viscosity solutions by a completely different method from the smooth case.

title: Higher integrability for anisotropic parabolic systems of p-Laplace type
abstract: Abstract In this article, we consider anisotropic parabolic systems of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:math> p -Laplace type. The model case is the parabolic <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {p}_{i} -Laplace system <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:munderover> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àë</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:munderover> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">‚à£</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>D</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">‚à£</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>D</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> {u}_{t}-\mathop{\sum }\limits_{i=1}^{n}\frac{\partial }{\partial {x}_{i}}({| {D}_{i}u| }^{{p}_{i}-2}{D}_{i}u)=0 with exponents <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>i</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> {p}_{i}\ge 2 . Under the assumption that the exponents are not too far apart, i.e., the difference <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>max</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>min</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {p}_{\max }-{p}_{\min } is sufficiently small, we establish a higher integrability result for weak solutions. This extends a result, which was only known for the elliptic setting, to the parabolic setting.

title: Lam√© system with weak damping and nonlinear time-varying delay
authors: Xin‚ÄêGuang Yang; Shubin Wang; Marcio A. Jorge Silva
abstract: Abstract This article is concerned with the stability and dynamics for the weak damped Lam√© system with nonlinear time-varying delay in a bounded domain. Under some appropriate assumptions, the global well-posedness and asymptotic stability are shown in the case where the delay coefficient is upper dominated by the damping one. Moreover, the finite dimensional global and exponential attractors have also been presented by relying on quasi-stability arguments. The results in this article is an extension of Ma, Mesquita, and Seminario-Huertas‚Äôs recent work [ Smooth dynamics of weakly damped Lam√© systems with delay , SIAM J. Math. Anal. 53 (2021), no. 4, 3759‚Äì3771].

title: Global well posedness for the semilinear edge-degenerate parabolic equations on singular manifolds
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study the long-time dynamical behavior of the solution for a class of semilinear edge-degenerate parabolic equations on manifolds with edge singularities. By introducing a family of potential well and compactness method, we reveal the dependence between the initial data and the long-time dynamical behavior of the solution. Specifically, we give the threshold condition for the initial data, which makes the solution exist globally or blowup in finite-time with subcritical, critical, and supercritical initial energy, respectively. Moreover, we also discussed the long-time behavior of the global solution, the estimate of blowup time, and blowup rate. Our results show that the relationship between the initial data and the long-time behavior of the solution can be revealed in the weighted Sobolev spaces for nonlinear parabolic equations on manifolds with edge singularities.

title: Blowup in L 1(Œ©)-norm and global existence for time-fractional diffusion equations with polynomial semilinear terms
authors: Giuseppe Floridia; Yikan Liu; Masahiro Yamamoto
abstract: Abstract This article is concerned with semilinear time-fractional diffusion equations with polynomial nonlinearity <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {u}^{p} in a bounded domain <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:math> \Omega with the homogeneous Neumann boundary condition and positive initial values. In the case of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> p\gt 1 , we prove the blowup of solutions <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> u\left(x,t) in the sense that <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Äñ</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mspace width="0.33em"/> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> <m:mspace width="0.33em"/> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚Äñ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> \Vert u\left(\hspace{0.33em}\cdot \hspace{0.33em},t){\Vert }_{{L}^{1}\left(\Omega )} tends to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:math> \infty as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:math> t approaches some value, by using a comparison principle for the corresponding ordinary differential equations and constructing special lower solutions. Moreover, we provide an upper bound for the blowup time. In the case of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> 0\lt p\lt 1 , we establish the global existence of solutions in time based on the Schauder fixed-point theorem.

title: Carleman estimates and null controllability of a class of singular parabolic equations
authors: Runmei Du; J√ºrgen Eichhorn; Qiang Liu; Chunpeng Wang
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider control systems governed by a class of semilinear parabolic equations, which are singular at the boundary and possess singular convection and reaction terms. The systems are shown to be null controllable by establishing Carleman estimates, observability inequalities and energy estimates for solutions to linearized equations.

title: Clustered solutions for supercritical elliptic equations on Riemannian manifolds
abstract: Abstract Let {(M,g)} be a smooth compact Riemannian manifold of dimension {n\geq 5} . We are concerned with the following elliptic problem: -\Delta_{g}u+a(x)u=u^{\frac{n+2}{n-2}+\varepsilon},\quad u>0\text{ in }M, where {\Delta_{g}=\mathrm{div}_{g}(\nabla)} is the Laplace‚ÄìBeltrami operator on M , {a(x)} is a {C^{2}} function on M such that the operator {-\Delta_{g}+a} is coercive, and {\varepsilon>0} is a small real parameter. Using the Lyapunov‚ÄìSchmidt reduction procedure, we obtain that the problem under consideration has a k -peaks solution for positive integer {k\geq 2} , which blow up and concentrate at one point in M .

title: Critical elliptic systems involving multiple strongly‚Äìcoupled Hardy‚Äìtype terms
authors: Dongsheng Kang; Mengru Liu; Liangshun Xu
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study the radially‚Äìsymmetric and strictly‚Äìdecreasing solutions to a system of critical elliptic equations in R N , which involves multiple critical nonlinearities and strongly‚Äìcoupled Hardy‚Äì type terms. By the ODEs analysis methods, the asymptotic behaviors at the origin and infinity of solutions are proved. It is found that the singularities of u and v in the solution ( u , v ) are at the same level. Finally, an explicit form of least energy solutions is found under certain assumptions, which has all of the mentioned properties for the radial decreasing solutions.

title: Normalized multi-bump solutions for saturable Schr√∂dinger equations
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we are concerned with the existence of multi-bump solutions for a class of semiclassical saturable Schr√∂dinger equations with an density function: $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle -{\it\Delta} v +{\it\Gamma} \frac{I(\varepsilon x) + v^2}{1+I(\varepsilon x) +v^2} v =\lambda v,\, x\in{{\mathbb{R}}^{2}}. \end{array}$$ We prove that, with the density function being radially symmetric, for given integer k ‚â• 2 there exist a family of non-radial, k -bump type normalized solutions (i.e., with the L 2 constraint) which concentrate at the global maximum points of density functions when Œµ ‚Üí 0 + . The proof is based on a variational method in particular on a convexity technique and the concentration-compactness method.

title: A singularity as a break point for the multiplicity of solutions to quasilinear elliptic problems
abstract: Abstract In this paper we deal with the elliptic problem $$\begin{array}{} \begin{cases} \displaystyle-{\it\Delta} u=\lambda u+\mu(x)\frac{|\nabla u|^q}{u^\alpha}+f(x)\quad &\text{ in }{\it\Omega}, \\ u \gt 0 \quad &\text{ in }{\it\Omega}, \\ u=0\quad &\text{ on }\partial{\it\Omega}, \end{cases} \end{array} $$ where Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N is a bounded smooth domain, 0 ‚â® Œº ‚àà L ‚àû ( Œ© ), 0 ‚â® f ‚àà L p 0 ( Œ© ) for some p 0 > $\begin{array}{} \frac{N}{2} \end{array}$ , 1 < q < 2, Œ± ‚àà [0 1] and Œª ‚àà ‚Ñù. We establish existence and multiplicity results for Œª > 0 and Œ± < q ‚Äì 1, including the non-singular case Œ± = 0. In contrast, we also derive existence and uniqueness results for Œª > 0 and q ‚Äì 1 < Œ± ‚â§ 1. We thus complement the results in [1, 2], which are concerned with Œ± = q ‚Äì 1, and show that the value Œ± = q ‚Äì 1 plays the role of a break point for the multiplicity/uniqueness of solution.

title: On a degenerate hyperbolic problem for the 3-D steady full Euler equations with axial-symmetry
abstract: Abstract The transonic channel flow problem is one of the most important problems in mathematical fluid dynamics. The structure of solutions near the sonic curve is a key part of the whole transonic flow problem. This paper constructs a local classical hyperbolic solution for the 3-D axisymmetric steady compressible full Euler equations with boundary data given on the degenerate hyperbolic curve. By introducing a novel set of dependent and independent variables, we use the idea of characteristic decomposition to transform the axisymmetric Euler equations as a new system which has explicitly singularity-regularity structures. We first establish a local classical solution for the new system in a weighted metric space and then convert the solution in terms of the original variables.

title: Boundary value problems associated with singular strongly nonlinear equations with functional terms
authors: Stefano Biagi; Alessandro Calamai; Cristina Marcelli; Francesca Papalini
abstract: Abstract We study boundary value problems associated with singular, strongly nonlinear differential equations with functional terms of type <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mo maxsize="1.2em" minsize="1.2em">(</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mi class="MJX-tex-mathit" mathvariant="italic">Œ¶</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>k</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mspace width="thinmathspace" /><m:msup><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo>‚Ä≤</m:mo></m:msup><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:msup><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mo maxsize="1.2em" minsize="1.2em">)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>‚Ä≤</m:mo></m:msup><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>f</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:msub><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mi class="MJX-tex-caligraphic" mathvariant="script">G</m:mi></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mi>x</m:mi></m:msub><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mspace width="thinmathspace" /><m:mi>œÅ</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:msup><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo>‚Ä≤</m:mo></m:msup><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mo>,</m:mo></m:math> $$\big({\it \Phi}(k(t)\,x'(t))\big)' + f(t,{{\mathcal{G}}}_x(t))\,\rho(t, x'(t)) = 0,$$ on a compact interval [ a , b ]. These equations are quite general due to the presence of a strictly increasing homeomorphism Œ¶ , the so-called Œ¶ -Laplace operator, of a non-negative function k , which may vanish on a set of null measure, and moreover of a functional term G x . We look for solutions, in a suitable weak sense, which belong to the Sobolev space W 1,1 ([ a , b ]). Under the assumptions of the existence of a well-ordered pair of upper and lower solutions and of a suitable Nagumo-type growth condition, we prove an existence result by means of fixed point arguments.

title: Periodic solutions for a differential inclusion problem involving the p(t)-Laplacian
abstract: Abstract In the present paper, we consider the nonlinear periodic systems involving variable exponent driven by p ( t )-Laplacian with a locally Lipschitz nonlinearity. Our arguments combine the variational principle for locally Lipschitz functions with the properties of the generalized Lebesgue-Sobolev space. Applying the non-smooth critical point theory, we establish some new existence results.

title: Blow-up solutions with minimal mass for nonlinear Schr√∂dinger equation with variable potential
abstract: Abstract This paper studies the mass-critical variable coefficient nonlinear Schr√∂dinger equation. We first get the existence of the ground state by solving a minimization problem. Then we prove a compactness result by the variational characterization of the ground state solutions. In addition, we construct the blow-up solutions at the minimal mass threshold and further prove the uniqueness result on the minimal mass blow-up solutions which are pseudo-conformal transformation of the ground states.

title: Approximate nonradial solutions for the Lane-Emden problem in the ball
authors: Borb√°la Fazekas; Filomena Pacella; Michael Plum
abstract: Abstract In this paper we provide a numerical approximation of bifurcation branches from nodal radial solutions of the Lane Emden Dirichlet problem in the unit ball in ‚Ñù 2 , as the exponent of the nonlinearity varies. We consider solutions with two or three nodal regions. In the first case our numerical results complement the analytical ones recently obtained in [11]. In the case of solutions with three nodal regions, for which no analytical results are available, our analysis gives numerical evidence of the existence of bifurcation branches. We also compute additional approximations indicating presence of an unexpected branch of solutions with six nodal regions. In all cases the numerical results allow to formulate interesting conjectures.

title: Multiplicity of positive solutions for a degenerate nonlocal problem with p-Laplacian
authors: Pasquale Candito; Leszek Gasi≈Ñski; Roberto Livrea; Jo√£o R. Santos J√∫nior
abstract: Abstract We consider a nonlinear boundary value problem with degenerate nonlocal term depending on the L q -norm of the solution and the p -Laplace operator. We prove the multiplicity of positive solutions for the problem, where the number of solutions doubles the number of ‚Äúpositive bumps‚Äù of the degenerate term. The solutions are also ordered according to their L q -norms.

title: New asymptotically quadratic conditions for Hamiltonian elliptic systems

Here f ( s ) = ms + g ( s ) where m ‚â• 0 (constant) and g ‚àà C 2 [0, r ) ‚à© C [0, ‚àû) for some r > 0. In particular, we discuss the existence of multiple positive solutions for certain ranges of Œª leading to the occurrence of Œ£ -shaped bifurcation diagrams. We establish our multiplicity results via the method of sub-supersolutions.

title: A class of degenerate elliptic eigenvalue problems
abstract: Abstract. We consider a general class of eigenvalue problems where the leading elliptic term corresponds to a convex homogeneous energy function that is not necessarily differentiable. We derive a strong maximum principle and show uniqueness of the first eigenfunction. Moreover we prove the existence of a sequence of eigensolutions by using a critical point theory in metric spaces. Our results extend the eigenvalue problem of the p -Laplace operator to a much more general setting.

title: Weak solutions for p-Laplacian equation
authors: V. Bhuvaneswari; L. Shangerganesh; K. Balachandran
abstract: In this work we consider the p-Laplacian type parabolic equation with Dirichlet boundary condition and establish the existence of weak solutions using Leray‚ÄìSchauder's fixed point theorem and semi-discretization process.

title: Semigroup estimates and fast-slow dynamics in parabolic-hyperbolic systems
abstract: Abstract We present a general procedure to describe slow dynamics in parabolic-hyperbolic systems, under suitable assumptions on the terms appearing in the equations. In particular, our strategy relies in semigroup estimates for the evolution system associated to the family of time-dependent linearized operators around an interfaced configuration. We finally apply the general strategy to the explicit example of an hyperbolic system with relaxation.

title: Boundary layers to a singularly perturbed Klein‚ÄìGordon‚ÄìMaxwell‚ÄìProca system on a compact Riemannian manifold with boundary
authors: M√≥nica Clapp; Marco Ghimenti; Anna Maria Micheletti
abstract: Abstract We study the semiclassical limit to a singularly perturbed nonlinear Klein‚ÄìGordon‚ÄìMaxwell‚ÄìProca system, with Neumann boundary conditions, on a Riemannian manifold <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>ùîê</m:mi> </m:math> {\mathfrak{M}} with boundary. We exhibit examples of manifolds, of arbitrary dimension, on which these systems have a solution which concentrates at a closed submanifold of the boundary of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>ùîê</m:mi> </m:math> {\mathfrak{M}} , forming a positive layer, as the singular perturbation parameter goes to zero. Our results allow supercritical nonlinearities and apply, in particular, to bounded domains in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{N}} . Similar results are obtained for the more classical electrostatic Klein‚ÄìGordon‚ÄìMaxwell system with appropriate boundary conditions.

title: Uniqueness and comparison principles for semilinear equations and inequalities in Carnot groups
abstract: Abstract Variants of the Kato inequality are proved for distributional solutions of semilinear equations and inequalities on Carnot groups. Various applications to uniqueness, comparison of solutions and Liouville theorems are presented.

title: MaximalLp-Lqregularity to the Stokes problem with Navier boundary conditions
abstract: Abstract We prove in this paper some results on the complex and fractional powers of the Stokes operator with slip frictionless boundary conditions involving the stress tensor. This is fundamental and plays an important role in the associated parabolic problem and will be used to prove maximal <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mi>L</m:mi><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:msup></m:math> L^{p} - <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mi>L</m:mi><m:mi>q</m:mi></m:msup></m:math> L^{q} regularity results for the non-homogeneous Stokes problem.

title: Nondegeneracy of positive solutions to nonlinear Hardy‚ÄìSobolev equations

title: Advances in Nonlinear Analysis
Uniqueness of limit flow for a class of quasi-linear parabolic equations
abstract: Abstract We investigate the issue of uniqueness of the limit flow for a relevant class of quasi-linear parabolic equations defined on the whole space. More precisely, we shall investigate conditions which guarantee that the global solutions decay at infinity uniformly in time and their entire trajectory approaches a single steady state as time goes to infinity. Finally, we obtain a characterization of solutions which blow up, vanish or converge to a stationary state for initial data of the form <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>œÜ</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${\lambda\varphi_{0}}$ while <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${\lambda>0}$ crosses a bifurcation value <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:msub> </m:math> ${\lambda_{0}}$ .

title: On singularly weighted generalized Laplacian systems and their applications
abstract: Abstract We study the homogeneous Dirichlet boundary value problem of generalized Laplacian systems with a singular weight which may not be integrable. Some explicit intervals which correspond to the existence and nonexistence of positive solutions for the system with the finite asymptotic behaviors of the nonlinearities at 0 and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:math> {\infty} are obtained.

title: Equilibrium of a production economy with non-compact attainable allocations set
authors: Senda Ounaies; Jean‚ÄêMarc Bonnisseau; Souhail Chebbi
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider a production economy with an unbounded attainable set where the consumers may have non-complete non-transitive preferences. To get the existence of an equilibrium, we provide an asymptotic property on preferences for the attainable consumptions and we use a combination of the nonlinear optimization and fixed point theorems on truncated economies together with an asymptotic argument. We show that this condition holds true if the set of attainable allocations is compact or, when the preferences are representable by utility functions, if the set of attainable individually rational utility levels is compact. This assumption generalizes the CPP condition of [N. Allouch, An equilibrium existence result with short selling, J. Math. Econom. 37 2002, 2, 81‚Äì94] and covers the example of [F. H. Page, Jr., M. H. Wooders and P. K. Monteiro, Inconsequential arbitrage, J. Math. Econom. 34 2000, 4, 439‚Äì469] when the attainable utility levels set is not compact. So we extend the previous existence results with non-compact attainable sets in two ways by adding a production sector and considering general preferences.

title: On the moving plane method for boundary blow-up solutions to semilinear elliptic equations

We also prove the radial symmetry of the solutions in the case of annular domains.

title: Localization and multiplicity in the homogenization of nonlinear problems
abstract: Abstract We propose a method for the localization of solutions for a class of nonlinear problems arising in the homogenization theory. The method combines concepts and results from the linear theory of PDEs, linear periodic homogenization theory, and nonlinear functional analysis. Particularly, we use the Moser-Harnack inequality, arguments of fixed point theory and Ekeland's variational principle. A significant gain in the homogenization theory of nonlinear problems is that our method makes possible the emergence of finitely or infinitely many solutions.

title: Homoclinics for singular strong force Lagrangian systems
authors: Marek Izydorek; Joanna Janczewska; Jean Mawhin
abstract: Abstract We study the existence of homoclinic solutions for a class of Lagrangian systems $\begin{array}{} \frac{d}{dt} \end{array} $ (‚àá Œ¶ ( uÃá ( t ))) + ‚àá u V ( t , u ( t )) = 0, where t ‚àà ‚Ñù, Œ¶ : ‚Ñù 2 ‚Üí [0, ‚àû) is a G -function in the sense of Trudinger, V : ‚Ñù √ó (‚Ñù 2 ‚àñ { Œæ }) ‚Üí ‚Ñù is a C 1 -smooth potential with a single well of infinite depth at a point Œæ ‚àà ‚Ñù 2 ‚àñ {0} and a unique strict global maximum 0 at the origin. Under a strong force condition around the singular point Œæ , via minimization of an action integral, we will prove the existence of at least two geometrically distinct homoclinic solutions u ¬± : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù 2 ‚àñ { Œæ }.

title: Generalized solutions of variational problems and applications
authors: Vieri Benci; Lorenzo Luperi Baglini; Marco Squassina
abstract: Abstract Ultrafunctions are a particular class of generalized functions defined on a hyperreal field <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi><m:mo>*</m:mo></m:msup><m:mo>‚äÉ</m:mo><m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi></m:mrow></m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{*}\supset\mathbb{R}} that allow to solve variational problems with no classical solutions. We recall the construction of ultrafunctions and we study the relationships between these generalized solutions and classical minimizing sequences. Finally, we study some examples to highlight the potential of this approach.

title: Cahn‚ÄìHilliard equation on the boundary with bulk condition of Allen‚ÄìCahn type
abstract: Abstract The well-posedness of a system of partial differential equations with dynamic boundary conditions is discussed. This system is a sort of transmission problem between the dynamics in the bulk Œ© and on the boundary Œì. The Poisson equation for the chemical potential and the Allen‚ÄìCahn equation for the order parameter in the bulk Œ© are considered as auxiliary conditions for solving the Cahn‚ÄìHilliard equation on the boundary Œì. Recently, the well-posedness of this equation with a dynamic boundary condition, both of Cahn‚ÄìHilliard type, was discussed. Based on this result, the existence of the solution and its continuous dependence on the data are proved.

title: Some inequalities and superposition operator in the space of regulated functions
abstract: Abstract Some inequalities connected to measures of noncompactness in the space of regulated function R ( J , E ) were proved in the paper. The inequalities are analogous of well known estimations for Hausdorff measure and the space of continuous functions. Moreover two sufficient and necessary conditions that superposition operator (Nemytskii operator) can act from R ( J , E ) into R ( J , E ) are presented. Additionally, sufficient and necessary conditions that superposition operator F f : R ( J , E ) ‚Üí R ( J , E ) was compact are given.

title: Lack of smoothing for bounded solutions of a semilinear parabolic equation
abstract: Abstract We study a semilinear parabolic equation that possesses global bounded weak solutions whose gradient has a singularity in the interior of the domain for all t > 0. The singularity of these solutions is of the same type as the singularity of a stationary solution to which they converge as t ‚Üí ‚àû.

title: Gradient estimate of a variable power for nonlinear elliptic equations with Orlicz growth
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we prove a global Calder√≥n-Zygmund type estimate in the framework of Lorentz spaces for a variable power of the gradients to the zero-Dirichlet problem of general nonlinear elliptic equations with the nonlinearities satisfying Orlicz growth. It is mainly assumed that the variable exponents p ( x ) satisfy the log-H√∂lder continuity, while the nonlinearity and underlying domain ( A , Œ© ) is ( Œ¥ , R 0 )-vanishing in x ‚àà Œ© .

title: Deformation techniques in metric critical point theory
abstract: We propose a synthetic and self-contained treatment of the main deformation results of critical point theory, for continuous functionals defined on metric spaces.

title: Solutions of an anisotropic nonlocal problem involving variable exponent
abstract: The present paper deals with an anisotropic Kirchhoff problem under homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions, set in a bounded smooth domain of ‚ÑùN (). The problem studied is a stationary version of the original Kirchhoff equation, involving the anisotropic -Laplacian operator, in the framework of the variable exponent Lebesgue and Sobolev spaces. The question of the existence of weak solutions is treated. Applying the Mountain Pass Theorem of Ambrosetti and Rabinowitz, the existence of a nontrivial weak solution is obtained in the anisotropic variable exponent Sobolev space , provided that the positive parameter Œª that multiplies the nonlinearity f is small enough.

title: A multiplicity result for the scalar field equation
abstract: Abstract We prove the existence of N - 1 distinct pairs of nontrivial solutions of the scalar field equation in ‚Ñù N under a slow decay condition on the potential near infinity, without any symmetry assumptions. Our result gives more solutions than the existing results in the literature when N ‚â• 6. When the ground state is the only positive solution, we also obtain the stronger result that at least N - 1 of the first N minimax levels are critical, i.e., we locate our solutions on particular energy levels with variational characterizations. Finally we prove a symmetry breaking result when the potential is radial. To overcome the difficulties arising from the lack of compactness we use the concentration compactness principle of Lions, expressed as a suitable profile decomposition for critical sequences.

title: On a comparison theorem for parabolic equations with nonlinear boundary conditions
abstract: Abstract In this article, a new type of comparison theorem for some second-order nonlinear parabolic systems with nonlinear boundary conditions is given, which can cover classical linear boundary conditions, such as the homogeneous Dirichlet or Neumann boundary condition. The advantage of our comparison theorem over the classical ones lies in the fact that it enables us to compare two solutions satisfying different types of boundary conditions. As an application of our comparison theorem, we can give some new results on the existence of blow-up solutions of some parabolic equations and systems with nonlinear boundary conditions.

title: Lower and upper estimates of semi-global and global solutions to mixed-type functional differential equations
abstract: Abstract In the paper, nonlinear systems of mixed-type functional differential equations are analyzed and the existence of semi-global and global solutions is proved. In proofs, the monotone iterative technique and Schauder-Tychonov fixed-point theorem are used. In addition to proving the existence of global solutions, estimates of their co-ordinates are derived as well. Linear variants of results are considered and the results are illustrated by selected examples.

title: Entire solutions of certain fourth order elliptic problems and related inequalities
abstract: Abstract We study distributional solutions of semilinear biharmonic equations of the type <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mi>Œî</m:mi><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:msup><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>f</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mi mathvariant="italic">on</m:mi><m:msup><m:mo>‚Ñù</m:mo><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:msup><m:mo>,</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> {\Delta ^2}u + f(u) = 0\quad on\;{{\mathbb R} ^N}, where f is a continuous function satisfying f ( t ) t ‚â• c | t | q +1 for all t ‚àà ‚Ñù with c > 0 and q > 1. By using a new approach mainly based on careful choice of suitable weighted test functions and a new version of Hardy- Rellich inequalities, we prove several Liouville theorems independently of the dimension N and on the sign of the solutions.

title: Homoclinic solutions for a differential inclusion system involving the p(t)-Laplacian
authors: Jun Cheng; Peng Chen; Limin Zhang
abstract: Abstract The aim of this article is to study nonlinear problem driven by the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(t) -Laplacian with nonsmooth potential. We establish the existence of homoclinic solutions by using variational principle for locally Lipschitz functions and the properties of the generalized Lebesgue-Sobolev space under two cases of the nonsmooth potential: periodic and nonperiodic, respectively. The resulting problem engages two major difficulties: first, due to the appearance of the variable exponent, commonly known methods and techniques for studying constant exponent equations fail in the setting of problems involving variable exponents. Another difficulty we must overcome is verifying the link geometry and certifying boundedness of the Palais-Smale sequence. To our best knowledge, our theorems appear to be the first such result about homoclinic solution for differential inclusion system involving the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>t</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(t) -Laplacian.

title: Orbital stability of the trains of peaked solitary waves for the modified Camassa-Holm-Novikov equation
abstract: Abstract Consideration herein is the stability issue of peaked solitary wave solution for the modified Camassa-Holm-Novikov equation, which is derived from the shallow water theory. This wave configuration accommodates the ordered trains of the modified Camassa-Holm-Novikov-peaked solitary solution. With the application of conservation laws and the monotonicity property of the localized energy functionals, we prove the orbital stability of this wave profile in the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {H}^{1}\left({\mathbb{R}}) energy space according to the modulation argument.

</m:mtable> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> </m:math> \left\{\begin{array}{ll}-\Delta u=f\left(x),\hspace{1.0em}& \hspace{0.1em}\text{in}\hspace{0.1em}\hspace{0.33em}\Omega ,\\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial \nu }+\lambda \left(x)u=\frac{g\left(x)}{{u}^{\eta }},\hspace{1.0em}& \hspace{0.1em}\text{on}\hspace{0.1em}\hspace{0.33em}\partial \Omega ,\end{array}\right. where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ∑</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> \eta \ge 0 and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:math> f,\lambda , and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>g</m:mi> </m:math> g are the nonnegative integrable functions. The set <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \Omega \subset {{\mathbb{R}}}^{N}\left(N\gt 2) is open and bounded with smooth boundary, and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>ŒΩ</m:mi> </m:math> \nu denotes its unit outward normal vector. More generally, we handle equations driven by monotone operators of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:math> p -Laplacian type jointly with nonlinear boundary conditions. We prove the existence of an entropy solution and check that, under natural assumptions, this solution is unique. Among other features, we study the regularizing effect given to the solution by both the absorption and the nonlinear boundary term.

title: k-convex solutions for multiparameter Dirichlet systems with k-Hessian operator and Lane-Emden type nonlinearities
authors: Xingyue He; Chenghua Gao; Jingjing Wang

title: On optimal control in a nonlinear interface problem described by hemivariational inequalities
abstract: Abstract This article is devoted to the existence of optimal controls in various control problems associated with a novel nonlinear interface problem on an unbounded domain with non-monotone set-valued transmission conditions. This interface problem involves a nonlinear monotone partial differential equation in the interior domain and the Laplacian in the exterior domain. Such a scalar interface problem models non-monotone frictional contact of elastic infinite media. The variational formulation of the interface problem leads to a hemivariational inequality (HVI), which, however, lives on the unbounded domain, and thus cannot be analyzed in a reflexive Banach space setting. Boundary integral methods lead to another HVI that is amenable to functional analytic methods using standard Sobolev spaces on the interior domain and Sobolev spaces of fractional order on the coupling boundary. Broadening the scope of this article, we consider extended real-valued HVIs augmented by convex extended real-valued functions. Under a smallness hypothesis, we provide existence and uniqueness results; moreover, we establish a stability result with respect to the extended real-valued function as a parameter. Based on the latter stability result, we prove the existence of optimal controls for four kinds of optimal control problems: distributed control on the bounded domain, boundary control, simultaneous boundary-distributed control governed by the interface problem, and control of the obstacle driven by a related bilateral obstacle interface problem.

title: Standing waves for Choquard equation with noncritical rotation
authors: Yi-cen Mao; Jie Yang; Yu Su
abstract: Abstract We investigate the existence and stability of standing waves with prescribed mass <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>c</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> c\gt 0 for Choquard equation with noncritical rotation in Bose-Einstein condensation. Then, we consider the mass collapse behavior of standing waves, the ratio of energy to mass and the Lagrange multiplier, as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>c</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> c\to {0}^{+} . Our results extend the existing results.

title: Boundedness, existence and uniqueness results for coupled gradient dependent elliptic systems with nonlinear boundary condition
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study coupled elliptic systems with gradient dependent right-hand sides and nonlinear boundary conditions, where the left-hand sides are driven by so-called double phase operators. By applying a surjectivity result for pseudomonotone operators along with an equivalent norm in the function space, we prove that the system has at least one nontrivial solution under very general assumptions on the data. Under slightly stronger conditions, we are also able to show that this solution is unique. As a result of independent interest, we further prove the boundedness of solutions to such elliptic systems by employing Moser‚Äôs iteration scheme.

title: Time decay estimates of solutions to a two-phase flow model in the whole space
authors: Yakui Wu; Qiong Wu; Yue Zhang
abstract: Abstract In this article, we aim to establish the optimal time decay rates of strong solutions to a two-phase flow model derived from a type of coupled fluid-kinetic equation. It is proved that the strong solutions converge to the given constant states with algebraic time decay rates under some additional assumptions on the initial data.

title: Bounds for the sum of the first k-eigenvalues of Dirichlet problem with logarithmic order of Klein-Gordon operators

The purpose of this study is to obtain the upper and lower bounds for the sum of the first k -eigenvalues by extending the Li-Yau‚Äôs method and Kr√∂ger‚Äôs method, respectively.

title: Quasiconvex bulk and surface energies: C 1,Œ± regularity
authors: Menita Carozza; Luca Esposito; Lorenzo Lamberti
abstract: Abstract We establish regularity results for equilibrium configurations of vectorial multidimensional variational problems, involving bulk and surface energies. The bulk energy densities are uniformly strictly quasiconvex functions with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:math> p -growth, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> p\ge 2 , without any further structure conditions. The anisotropic surface energy is defined by means of an elliptic integrand <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ¶</m:mi> </m:math> \Phi not necessarily regular. For a minimal configuration <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>E</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left(u,E) , we prove partial H√∂lder continuity of the gradient <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àá</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:math> \nabla u of the deformation.

title: The second Yamabe invariant with boundary

As a generalization of the Yamabe invariant with boundary <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Y</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> Y\left(M,\partial M,g) , we define the k th Yamabe invariant with boundary <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Y</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {Y}_{k}\left(M,\partial M,g) . We prove some of its properties and study when it can be attained by the generalized metric. We also prove a version of conformal Schwarz lemma on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo> <m:mi>M</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>g</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left(M,\partial M,g) by using the Yamabe flow with boundary.

title: Peaked solitary waves and shock waves of the Degasperis-Procesi-Kadomtsev-Petviashvili equation
abstract: Abstract In this study, we establish the existence and nonexistence of smooth and peaked solitary wave solutions (or periodic) to the Degasperis-Procesi-Kadomtsev-Petviashvili (DP-KP) equation with a weak transverse effect. We have also shown that DP-KP equation possesses periodic shock waves similar to that of the Degasperis-Procesi equation.

title: Boundedness and long-time behavior in a parabolic-elliptic system arising from biological transport networks
abstract: Abstract The aim of this article is to consider a three-dimensional Cauchy problem for the parabolic-elliptic system arising from biological transport networks. For such problem, we first establish the global existence, uniqueness, and uniform boundedness of the strong solution by estimating the derivative of the diagonal permeability tensor with respect to time variable. Moreover, for the diffusion coefficient appropriately large, we demonstrate that the corresponding stationary problem admits a strong solution and that the solution of the Cauchy problem will stabilize to its stationary counterpart in infinite time with a time-decay rate.

title: Nonexistence of the compressible Euler equations with space-dependent damping in high dimensions

title: Nonlocal heat equations with generalized fractional Laplacian
abstract: Abstract We study heat equations with generalized fractional Laplacian, which is defined by the spectral theory. Here we develop the existence theory for those equations. Also, we present some numerical simulations for our problems.

title: Local and global well-posedness of the Maxwell-Bloch system of equations with inhomogeneous broadening
authors: Gino Biondini; B. Prinari; Zechuan Zhang
abstract: Abstract The Maxwell-Bloch system of equations with inhomogeneous broadening is studied, and the local and global well-posedness of the corresponding initial-boundary value problem is established by taking advantage of the integrability of the system and making use of the corresponding inverse scattering transform (IST). A key ingredient in the analysis is the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {L}^{2} -Sobolev bijectivity of the direct and IST established by Xin Zhou for the focusing Zakharov-Shabat problem.

title: Energy-variational solutions for viscoelastic fluid models
authors: Abramo Agosti; Robert Lasarzik; Elisabetta Rocca
abstract: Abstract In this article, we introduce the concept of energy-variational solutions for a class of nonlinear dissipative evolutionary equations, which turns out to be especially suited to treat viscoelastic fluid models. Under certain convexity assumptions, the existence of such solutions can be shown constructively by an adapted minimizing movement scheme in a general framework. Weak-strong uniqueness follows by a suitable relative energy inequality. Our main motivation is to apply the general framework to viscoelastic fluid models. Therefore, we give a short overview on different versions of such models and their derivation. The abstract result is applied to two of these viscoelastic fluid models in full detail. In the conclusion, we comment on further applications of the general theory and its possible impact.

title: Stability on 3D Boussinesq system with mixed partial dissipation
authors: Hongxia Lin; Sen Liu; Xiaochuan Guo; R. J. You
abstract: Abstract In the article, we are concerned with the three-dimensional anisotropic Boussinesq equations with the velocity dissipation in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {x}_{2} and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {x}_{3} directions and the thermal diffusion in only <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> </m:math> {x}_{3} direction. When the spatial domain is the whole space <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{3} , the global well-posedness and stability problem for the partially dissipated Boussinesq system remain the extremely challenging open problems. Attention here focuses on the periodic domain <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> <m:mo>√ó</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">T</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> \Omega ={\mathbb{R}}\times {{\mathbb{T}}}^{2} . We aim at establishing the stability for the problem of perturbations near hydrostatic equilibrium and the large-time behavior of the perturbed solution. We first obtain the global existence of some symmetric fluids in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {H}^{2}\left(\Omega ) for small initial data. Then the exponential decay rates for the oscillations <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="true">Àú</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mover> </m:math> \widetilde{u} and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ∏</m:mi> </m:math> \theta in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {H}^{1}\left(\Omega ) and the homogeneous Sobolev space <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>v</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>Àô</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mover> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \dot{{H}_{v}^{2}}\left(\Omega ) are also shown. The proof is based on a key observation that we can decompose the velocity <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:math> u into the average <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="true">¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mover> </m:math> \overline{u} on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">T</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {{\mathbb{T}}}^{2} and the corresponding oscillation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="true">Àú</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mover> </m:math> \widetilde{u} . This enables us to establish the strong Poincar√©-type inequalities on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="true">Àú</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mover> </m:math> \widetilde{u} , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ∏</m:mi> </m:math> {u}_{3},\theta and some anisotropic inequalities, which ensure the establishment of the closed priori estimates. In addition, we also prove the oscillations in one direction <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="true">Àú</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mover> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mover accent="true"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="true">Àú</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mover> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>3</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {\widetilde{u}}^{\left(2)},{\widetilde{u}}^{\left(3)} in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {H}^{1}\left(\Omega ) decay to zero exponentially.

title: Existence and multiplicity results for non-autonomous second-order Hamiltonian systems
abstract: Abstract In this article, using the least action principle and minimax methods in critical point theory, some existence and multiplicity results for periodic solutions of second-order Hamiltonian systems are obtained.

title: Non-stationary Navier‚ÄìStokes equations in 2D power cusp domain
abstract: Abstract The initial boundary value problem for the non-stationary Navier-Stokes equations is studied in 2D bounded domain with a power cusp singular point O on the boundary. The case of the boundary value with a nonzero flow rate is considered. In this case there is a source/sink in O and the solution necessary has infinite energy integral. In the first part of the paper the formal asymptotic expansion of the solution near the singular point is constructed. The justification of the asymptotic expansion and the existence of a solution are proved in the second part of the paper.

title: Lions-type theorem of thep-Laplacian and applications
abstract: Abstract In this article, our aim is to establish a generalized version of Lions-type theorem for the p -Laplacian. As an application of this theorem, we consider the existence of ground state solution for the quasilinear elliptic equation with the critical growth.

title: On singular quasilinear elliptic equations with data measures
authors: Nour Eddine Alaa; Fatima Aqel; Laila Taourirte
abstract: Abstract The aim of this work is to study a quasilinear elliptic equation with singular nonlinearity and data measure. Existence and non-existence results are obtained under necessary or sufficient conditions on the data, where the main ingredient is the isoperimetric inequality. Finally, uniqueness results for weak solutions are given.

title: Partial regularity of stable solutions to the fractional Geƒæfand-Liouville equation
abstract: Abstract We analyze stable weak solutions to the fractional Geƒæfand problem <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd> <m:mstyle displaystyle="true"> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi class="MJX-tex-mathit" mathvariant="italic">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>e</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mspace width="1em" /> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">i</m:mi> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">n</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mspace width="1em" /> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi class="MJX-tex-mathit" mathvariant="italic">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>.</m:mo> </m:mstyle> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:math> $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle (-{\it\Delta})^su = e^u\quad\mathrm{in}\quad {\it\Omega}\subset\mathbb{R}^n. \end{array}$$ We prove that the dimension of the singular set is at most n ‚àí 10 s .

title: Existence of single peak solutions for a nonlinear Schr√∂dinger system with coupled quadratic nonlinearity

v+P(x) v=\mu v w, & x \in \mathbb{R}^{N}, \\ -\varepsilon^{2} \Delta w+Q(x) w=\frac{\mu}{2} v^{2}+\gamma w^{2}, & x \in \mathbb{R}^{N}, \\ v>0, \quad w>0, & v, w \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{N}\right),\end{array}\right. \end{equation}$$ which arises from second-harmonic generation in quadratic media. Here Œµ > 0 is a small parameter, 2 ‚â§ N < 6, Œº > 0 and Œº > Œ≥, P ( x ), Q ( x ) are positive function potentials. By applying reduction method, we prove that if x 0 is a non-degenerate critical point of Œî ( P + Q ) on some closed N ‚àí 1 dimensional hypersurface, then the system above has a single peak solution ( v Œµ , w Œµ ) concentrating at x 0 for Œµ small enough.

title: Maximum principle for higher order operators in general domains
abstract: Abstract We first prove De Giorgi type level estimates for functions in W 1, t (Œ©), <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> $ \Omega\subset{\mathbb R}^N $ , with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> $ t \gt N\geq 2 $ . This augmented integrability enables us to establish a new Harnack type inequality for functions which do not necessarily belong to De Giorgi‚Äôs classes as obtained in Di Benedetto‚ÄìTrudinger [10] for functions in W 1,2 (Œ©). As a consequence, we prove the validity of the strong maximum principle for uniformly elliptic operators of any even order, in fairly general domains in dimension two and three, provided second order derivatives are taken into account.

title: Butterfly support for off diagonal coefficients and boundedness of solutions to quasilinear elliptic systems
authors: Salvatore Leonardi; Francesco Leonetti; Eug√©nio M. Rocha; Vasile Staicu
abstract: Abstract We consider quasilinear elliptic systems in divergence form. In general, we cannot expect that weak solutions are locally bounded because of De Giorgi‚Äôs counterexample. Here we assume that off-diagonal coefficients have a ‚Äúbutterfly support‚Äù: this allows us to prove local boundedness of weak solutions.

title: Diffusive logistic equations with harvesting and heterogeneity under strong growth rate
abstract: Abstract We consider the equation -\Delta u=au-b(x)u^{2}-ch(x)\quad\text{in }\Omega,\qquad u=0\quad\text{on }% \partial\Omega, where Œ© is a smooth bounded domain in {\mathbb{R}^{N}} , {b(x)} and {h(x)} are nonnegative functions, and there exists {\Omega_{0}\subset\subset\Omega} such that {\{x:b(x)=0\}=\overline{\Omega}_{0}} . We investigate the existence of positive solutions of this equation for c large under the strong growth rate assumption {a\geq\lambda_{1}(\Omega_{0})} , where {\lambda_{1}(\Omega_{0})} is the first eigenvalue of the {-\Delta} in {\Omega_{0}} with Dirichlet boundary condition. We show that if {h\equiv 0} in {\Omega\setminus\overline{\Omega}_{0}} , then our equation has a unique positive solution for all c large, provided that a is in a right neighborhood of {\lambda_{1}(\Omega_{0})} . For this purpose, we prove and utilize some new results on the positive solution set of this equation in the weak growth rate case.

title: The elliptic sinh-Gordon equation in a semi-strip
abstract: Abstract We study the elliptic sinh-Gordon equation posed in a semi-strip by applying the so-called Fokas method, a generalization of the inverse scattering transform for boundary value problems. Based on the spectral analysis for the Lax pair formulation, we show that the spectral functions can be characterized from the boundary values. We express the solution of the equation in terms of the unique solution of the matrix Riemann‚ÄìHilbert problem whose jump matrices are defined by the spectral functions. Moreover, we derive the global algebraic relation that involves the boundary values. In addition, it can be verified that the solution of the elliptic sinh-Gordon equation posed in the semi-strip exists if the spectral functions defined by the boundary values satisfy this global relation.

title: The Gelfand problem for the 1-homogeneous p-Laplacian
authors: Jos√© Carmona; Alexis Molino; Julio D. Rossi
abstract:
Abstract In this paper, we study the existence of viscosity solutions to the Gelfand problem for the 1-homogeneous p -Laplacian in a bounded domain {\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{N}} , that is, we deal with - rac{1}{p-1}\lvert
abla uvert^{2-p}\operatorname{div}(\lvert
abla u% vert^{p-2}
abla u)=\lambda e^{u} in Œ© with {u=0} on {\partial\Omega} . For this problem we show that, for {p\in[2,\infty]} , there exists a positive critical value {\lambda^{*}=\lambda^{*}(\Omega,N,p)} such that the following holds: ‚Ä¢ If {\lambda<\lambda^{*}} , the problem admits a minimal positive solution {w_{\lambda}} . ‚Ä¢ If {\lambda>\lambda^{*}} , the problem admits no solution. Moreover, the branch of minimal solutions {\{w_{\lambda}\}} is increasing with Œª. In addition, using degree theory, for fixed p we show that there exists an unbounded continuum of solutions that emanates from the trivial solution {u=0} with {\lambda=0} , and for a small fixed Œª we also obtain a continuum of solutions with {p\in[2,\infty]} .

title: On Cauchy‚ÄìLiouville-type theorems
abstract: Abstract In this paper we explore Liouville-type theorems to solutions of PDEs involving the œï-Laplace operator in the setting of Orlicz‚ÄìSobolev spaces. Our results extend Liouville-type theorems that have been obtained recently.

title: The Caccioppoli ultrafunctions
authors: Vieri Benci; Luigi C. Berselli; Carlo R. Grisanti
abstract: Abstract Ultrafunctions are a particular class of functions defined on a hyperreal field <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi><m:mo>‚àó</m:mo></m:msup><m:mo>‚äÉ</m:mo><m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi></m:mrow></m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{\ast}\supset\mathbb{R}} . They have been introduced and studied in some previous works [2, 6, 7]. In this paper we introduce a particular space of ultrafunctions which has special properties, especially in term of localization of functions together with their derivatives. An appropriate notion of integral is then introduced which allows to extend in a consistent way the integration by parts formula, the Gauss theorem and the notion of perimeter. This new space we introduce, seems suitable for applications to Partial Differential Equations and Calculus of Variations. This fact will be illustrated by a simple, but meaningful example.

title: Hypercontractivity, supercontractivity, ultraboundedness and stability in semilinear problems
authors: Davide Addona; Luciana Angiuli; Luca Lorenzi
abstract: Abstract We study the Cauchy problem associated to a family of nonautonomous semilinear equations in the space of bounded and continuous functions over <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>d</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{d}} and in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> {L^{p}} -spaces with respect to tight evolution systems of measures. Here, the linear part of the equation is a nonautonomous second-order elliptic operator with unbounded coefficients defined in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>I</m:mi> <m:mo>√ó</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>d</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {I\times\mathbb{R}^{d}} , ( I being a right-halfline). To the above Cauchy problem we associate a nonlinear evolution operator, which we study in detail, proving some summability improving properties. We also study the stability of the null solution to the Cauchy problem.

title: Multiple solutions for Dirichlet impulsive equations
abstract: Abstract In this paper we are interested to ensure the existence of multiple nontrivial solutions for some classes of problems under Dirichlet boundary conditions with impulsive effects. More precisely, by using a suitable analytical setting, the existence of at least three solutions is proved exploiting a recent three-critical points result for smooth functionals defined in a reflexive Banach space. Our approach generalizes some well-known results in the classical framework.

title: N-Laplacian critical problem with discontinuous nonlinearities
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study the existence of a solution of the N -Laplacian critical problem with discontinuous nonlinearity of Heaviside type in a smooth bounded domain with respect to a positive parameter Œª.

title: Multiple solutions for a class of oscillatory discrete problems
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study a discrete nonlinear boundary value problem that involves a nonlinear term oscillating at infinity and a power-type nonlinearity u p . By using variational methods, we establish the existence of a sequence of non-negative weak solutions that converges to +‚àû if 0 < p ‚â§ 1. In the superlinear case, we establish a sufficient condition for the existence of at least n solutions.

title: Radiative effects for some bidimensional thermoelectric problems
abstract: Abstract There are two main objectives in this paper. One is to find sufficient conditions to ensure the existence of weak solutions for some bidimensional thermoelectric problems. At the steady-state, these problems consist of a coupled system of elliptic equations of the divergence form, commonly accomplished with nonlinear radiation-type conditions on at least a nonempty part of the boundary of a <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>C</m:mi> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:msup> </m:math> ${C^{1}}$ domain. The model under study takes the thermoelectric Peltier and Seebeck effects into account, which describe the Joule‚ÄìThomson effect. The proof method requires a fixed point argument. To this end, well-determined estimates are our main concern. The second objective of the paper is the derivation of explicit <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>W</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> ${W^{1,p}}$ -estimates <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${(p>2)}$ for solutions of nonlinear radiation-type problems in the general n -dimensional space situation, where the leading coefficient is assumed to be a discontinuous function on the space variable. In particular, the behavior of the leading coefficient is conveniently explicit on the estimate of any solution.

title: Asymptotic behavior of evolution systems in arbitrary Banach spaces using general almost periodic splittings
abstract: Abstract We present sufficient conditions on the existence of solutions, with various specific almost periodicity properties, in the context of nonlinear, generally multivalued,
