title: Existence and multiplicity of solutions for a class of superlinear elliptic systems
authors: Li Chun; Ravi P. Agarwal; Dong‚ÄêLun Wu
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we establish the existence and multiplicity of solutions for a class of superlinear elliptic systems without Ambrosetti and Rabinowitz growth condition. Our results are based on minimax methods in critical point theory.

title: A concrete realization of the slow-fast alternative for a semilinear heat equation with homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions
authors: Marina Ghisi; Massimo Gobbino; Alain Haraux
abstract: Abstract We investigate the asymptotic behavior of solutions to a semilinear heat equation with homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions. It was recently shown that the nontrivial kernel of the linear part leads to the coexistence of fast solutions decaying to 0 exponentially (as time goes to infinity), and slow solutions decaying to 0 as negative powers of t . Here we provide a characterization of slow/fast solutions in terms of their sign, and we show that the set of initial data giving rise to fast solutions is a graph of codimension one in the phase space.

title: Multiple nontrivial solutions of superlinear fractional Laplace equations without (AR) condition
authors: Leiga Zhao; Hongrui Cai; Yutong Chen
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study a class of nonlinear fractional Laplace problems with a parameter and superlinear nonlinearity <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mfenced open="{" close=""> <m:mrow> <m:mspace depth="1.25em"/> <m:mtable displaystyle="true"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> </m:mtd> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mstyle> <m:mspace width="0.1em"/> <m:mtext>in</m:mtext> <m:mspace width="0.1em"/> </m:mstyle> <m:mspace width="0.33em"/> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> <m:mtr> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mspace width="1.0em"/> </m:mtd> <m:mtd columnalign="left"> <m:mstyle> <m:mspace width="0.1em"/> <m:mtext>in</m:mtext> <m:mspace width="0.1em"/> </m:mstyle> <m:mspace width="0.33em"/> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>\</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>.</m:mo> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:mrow> </m:mfenced> </m:math> \left\{\phantom{\rule[-1.25em]{}{0ex}}\begin{array}{ll}{\left(-\Delta )}^{s}u=\lambda u+f\left(x,u),\hspace{1.0em}& \hspace{0.1em}\text{in}\hspace{0.1em}\hspace{0.33em}\Omega ,\\ u=0,\hspace{1.0em}& \hspace{0.1em}\text{in}\hspace{0.1em}\hspace{0.33em}{{\mathbb{R}}}^{N}\backslash \Omega \right.\end{array}\right. Multiplicity of nontrivial solutions is obtained when the parameter is near the eigenvalue of the fractional Laplace operator without Ambrosetti and Rabinowitz condition for the nonlinearity. Our methods are the combination of minimax method, bifurcation theory, and Morse theory.

title: On the fractional Korn inequality in bounded domains: Counterexamples to the case ps < 1
abstract: Abstract The validity of Korn‚Äôs first inequality in the fractional setting in bounded domains has been open. We resolve this problem by proving that in fact Korn‚Äôs first inequality holds in the case <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> ps\gt 1 for fractional <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {W}_{0}^{s,p}\left(\Omega ) Sobolev fields in open and bounded <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{1} -regular domains <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> \Omega \subset {{\mathbb{R}}}^{n} . Also, in the case <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> ps\lt 1 , for any open bounded <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{1} domain <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> \Omega \subset {{\mathbb{R}}}^{n} , we construct counterexamples to the inequality, i.e., Korn‚Äôs first inequality fails to hold in bounded domains. The proof of the inequality in the case <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> ps\gt 1 follows a standard compactness approach adopted in the classical case, combined with a Hardy inequality, and a recently proven Korn second inequality by Mengesha and Scott [ A Fractional Korn-type inequality for smooth domains and a regularity estimate for nonlinear nonlocal systems of equations , Commun. Math. Sci. 20 (2022), no. 2, 405‚Äì423]. The counterexamples constructed in the case <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> ps\lt 1 are interpolations of a constant affine rigid motion inside the domain away from the boundary and of the zero field close to the boundary.

title: A survey on some vanishing viscosity limit results
authors: H. Beir√£o da Veiga; Francesca Crispo
abstract: Abstract We present a survey concerning the convergence, as the viscosity goes to zero, of the solutions to the three-dimensional evolutionary Navier-Stokes equations to solutions of the Euler equations. After considering the Cauchy problem, particular attention is given to the convergence under Navier slip-type boundary conditions. We show that, in the presence of flat boundaries (typically, the half-space case), convergence holds, uniformly in time, with respect to the initial data‚Äôs norm. In spite of this result (and of a similar result for arbitrary two-dimensional domains), strong inviscid limit results are proved to be false in general domains, in correspondence to a very large family of smooth initial data. In Section 6, we present a result in this direction.

title: Short-time existence of a quasi-stationary fluid‚Äìstructure interaction problem for plaque growth
abstract: Abstract We address a quasi-stationary fluid‚Äìstructure interaction problem coupled with cell reactions and growth, which comes from the plaque formation during the stage of the atherosclerotic lesion in human arteries. The blood is modeled by the incompressible Navier-Stokes equation, while the motion of vessels is captured by a quasi-stationary equation of nonlinear elasticity. The growth happens when both cells in fluid and solid react, diffuse and transport across the interface, resulting in the accumulation of foam cells, which are exactly seen as the plaques. Via a fixed-point argument, we derive the local well-posedness of the nonlinear system, which is sustained by the analysis of decoupled linear systems.

title: Global existence for time-dependent damped wave equations with nonlinear memory
authors: Mokhtar Kirane; Ahmad Z. Fino; Ahmed Alsaedi; Bashir Ahmad
abstract: Abstract In this article, we consider the Cauchy problem for a semi-linear wave equation with time-dependent damping and memory nonlinearity. Conditions for global existence are presented in the energy space <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>H</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>√ó</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>L</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> {H}^{1}\left({{\mathbb{R}}}^{n})\times {L}^{2}\left({{\mathbb{R}}}^{n}) , <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> n\ge 1 .

title: Regularity results for p-Laplacians in pre-fractal domains
authors: Raffaela Capitanelli; Salvatore Fragapane; Maria Agostina Vivaldi
abstract: Abstract We study obstacle problems involving p -Laplace-type operators in non-convex polygons. We establish regularity results in terms of weighted Sobolev spaces. As applications, we obtain estimates for the FEM approximation for obstacle problems in pre-fractal Koch Islands.

title: Ground state solutions for the H√©non prescribed mean curvature equation
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the analogous of the H√©non equation for the prescribed mean curvature problem in {{\mathbb{R}^{N}}} , both in the Euclidean and in the Minkowski spaces. Motivated by the studies of Ni and Serrin [W. M. Ni and J. Serrin, Existence and non-existence theorems for ground states for quasilinear partial differential equations, Att. Convegni Lincei 77 1985, 231‚Äì257], we have been interested in finding the relations between the growth of the potential and that of the local nonlinearity in order to prove the nonexistence of a radial ground state. We also present a partial result on the existence of a ground state solution in the Minkowski space.

title: Approximate solution of inhomogeneous fractional differential equation
authors: Biju Kumar Dutta; L. K. Arora
abstract: In this paper, we study the stability of a class of inhomogeneous fractional differential equations involving Caputo derivative. The approximate solutions have been studied.

title: Multiplicity results for some quasilinear equations in lack of symmetry
abstract: In this paper we prove the existence of multiple nontrivial solutions for the quasilinear equation in divergence form,

title: Global well-posedness of the full compressible Hall-MHD equations
abstract: Abstract This paper deals with a Cauchy problem of the full compressible Hall-magnetohydrodynamic flows. We establish the existence and uniqueness of global solution, provided that the initial energy is suitably small but the initial temperature allows large oscillations. In addition, the large time behavior of the global solution is obtained.

title: Ground state solutions to a class of critical Schr√∂dinger problem

title: Optimal decay rate for higher‚Äìorder derivatives of solution to the 3D compressible quantum magnetohydrodynamic model
abstract: Abstract We investigate optimal decay rates for higher‚Äìorder spatial derivatives of strong solutions to the 3D Cauchy problem of the compressible viscous quantum magnetohydrodynamic model in the H 5 √ó H 4 √ó H 4 framework, and the main novelty of this work is three‚Äìfold: First, we show that fourth order spatial derivative of the solution converges to zero at the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mtext>rate</m:mtext> <m:mo> </m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mn>11</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mn>4</m:mn> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {L^2} - {\rm{rate}}\,{(1 + t)^{- {{11} \over 4}}} , which is same as one of the heat equation, and particularly faster than the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mtext>rate</m:mtext> <m:mo> </m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mn>5</m:mn> <m:mn>4</m:mn> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {L^2} - {\rm{rate}}\,{(1 + t)^{- {5 \over 4}}} in Pu‚ÄìXu [Z. Angew. Math. Phys., 68:1, 2017] and the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mtext>rate</m:mtext> <m:mo> </m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mn>9</m:mn> <m:mn>4</m:mn> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {L^2} - {\rm{rate}}\,{(1 + t)^{- {9 \over 4}}} , in Xi‚ÄìPu‚ÄìGuo [Z. Angew. Math. Phys., 70:1, 2019]. Second, we prove that fifth‚Äìorder spatial derivative of density œÅ converges to zero at the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mtext>rate</m:mtext> <m:mo> </m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mn>13</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mn>4</m:mn> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {L^2} - {\rm{rate}}\,{(1 + t)^{- {{13} \over 4}}} , which is same as that of the heat equation, and particularly faster than ones of Pu‚ÄìXu [Z. Third, we show that the high-frequency part of the fourth order spatial derivatives of the velocity u and magnetic B converge to zero at the <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mtext>rate</m:mtext> <m:mo> </m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>t</m:mi> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mn>13</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mn>4</m:mn> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {L^2} - {\rm{rate}}\,{(1 + t)^{- {{13} \over 4}}} , which are faster than ones of themselves, and totally new as compared to Pu‚ÄìXu [Z. Angew. Math. Phys., 68:1, 2017] and Xi‚ÄìPu‚ÄìGuo [Z. Angew. Math. Phys., 70:1, 2019].

title: Continuous flows driving branching processes and their nonlinear evolution equations
abstract: Abstract We consider on M (‚Ñù d ) (the set of all finite measures on ‚Ñù d ) the evolution equation associated with the nonlinear operator <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>F</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Ü¶</m:mo> <m:mi>Œî</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mi>F</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Ä≤</m:mo> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mo>‚àë</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> <m:mo>‚©æ</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>b</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>F</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> F \mapsto \Delta F' + \sum\nolimits_{k \geqslant 1} b_k F^k , where F‚Ä≤ is the variational derivative of F and we show that it has a solution represented by means of the distribution of the d -dimensional Brownian motion and the non-local branching process on the finite configurations of M (‚Ñù d ), induced by the sequence ( b k ) k ‚©æ1 of positive numbers such that <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mo>‚àë</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> <m:mo>‚©æ</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msub> <m:msub> <m:mrow> <m:mi>b</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚©Ω</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> \sum\nolimits_{k \geqslant 1} b_k \leqslant 1 . It turns out that the representation also holds with the same branching process for the solution to the equation obtained replacing the Laplace operator by the generator of a Markov process on ‚Ñù d instead of the d -dimensional Brownian motion; more general, we can take the generator of a right Markov process on a Lusin topological space. We first investigate continuous flows driving branching processes. We show that if the branching mechanism of a superprocess is independent of the spatial variable, then the superprocess is obtained by introducing the branching in the time evolution of the right continuous flow on measures, canonically induced by a right continuous flow as spatial motion. A corresponding result holds for non-local branching processes on the set of all finite configurations of the state space of the spatial motion.

authors: Kazuhiro Ishige; Shinya Okabe; Tokushi Sato
abstract: Abstract In this paper we study the existence and the nonexistence of solutions to an inhomogeneous non-linear elliptic problem (P) <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><m:mrow><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mi>Œî</m:mi><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mi>F</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>Œ∫</m:mi><m:mi>Œº</m:mi><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mtext>in</m:mtext><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:msup><m:mi mathvariant="bold">R</m:mi><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:msup><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>></m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mtext>in</m:mtext><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:msup><m:mi mathvariant="bold">R</m:mi><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:msup><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mtext>as</m:mtext><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mo> </m:mo><m:mo>|</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo>|</m:mo><m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo><m:mi>‚àû</m:mi><m:mo>,</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> - \Delta u + u = F(u) + \kappa \mu \quad {\kern 1pt} {\rm in}{\kern 1pt} \quad {{\bf R}^N},\quad u > 0\quad {\kern 1pt} {\rm in}{\kern 1pt} \quad {{\bf R}^N},\quad u(x) \to 0\quad {\kern 1pt} {\rm as}{\kern 1pt} \quad |x| \to \infty , where F = F ( t ) grows up (at least) exponentially as t ‚Üí ‚àû. Here N ‚â• 2, Œ∫ > 0, and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><m:mrow><m:mi>Œº</m:mi><m:mo>‚àà</m:mo><m:msubsup><m:mi>L</m:mi><m:mtext>c</m:mtext><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:msubsup><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:msup><m:mi mathvariant="bold">R</m:mi><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:msup><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>\</m:mo><m:mo>{</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mo>}</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> \mu \in L_{\rm{c}}^1({{\bf R}^N})\backslash \{ 0\} is nonnegative. Then, under a suitable integrability condition on Œº , there exists a threshold parameter Œ∫ * > 0 such that problem (P) possesses a solution if 0 < Œ∫ < Œ∫ * and it does not possess no solutions if Œ∫ > Œ∫ * . Furthermore, in the case of 2 ‚â§ N ‚â§ 9, problem (P) possesses a unique solution if Œ∫ = Œ∫ * .

title: Nonstationary Poiseuille flow of a non-Newtonian fluid with the shear rate-dependent viscosity
abstract: Abstract A nonstationary Poiseuille flow of a non-Newtonian fluid with the shear rate dependent viscosity is considered. This problem is nonlinear and nonlocal in time and inverse to the nonlinear heat equation. The provided mathematical analysis includes the proof of the existence, uniqueness, regularity, and stability of the velocity and the pressure slope for a given flux carrier and of the exponential decay of the solution as the time variable goes to infinity for the exponentially decaying flux.

Observing that (0.1) is doubly coupled, we first develop two efficient tools (i.e., a refined Sobolev inequality and a variant of the ‚ÄúVanishing‚Äù lemma). On the previous tools, we will establish a global compactness result (i.e., a complete description for the Palais-Smale sequences of the corresponding energy functional) and some existence result for (0.1) via variational method. Our strategy turns out to be very concise because we avoid the use of Levy concentration functions and truncation techniques.

title: Quasilinear equations with indefinite nonlinearity
authors: Junfang Zhao; Xiangqing Liu; Zhaosheng Feng
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we are concerned with quasilinear equations with indefinite nonlinearity and explore the existence of infinitely many solutions.

title: On the weakly degenerate Allen-Cahn equation
abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider a one-dimensional Allen-Cahn equation with degeneracy in the interior of the domain and Neumann boundary conditions. We allow the diffusivity coefficient vanish at some point of the space domain and we are addressed on the existence of stable non-constant solution.

title: Global existence of a radiative Euler system coupled to an electromagnetic field
abstract: Abstract We study the Cauchy problem for a system of equations corresponding to a singular limit of radiative hydrodynamics, namely, the 3D radiative compressible Euler system coupled to an electromagnetic field. Assuming smallness hypotheses for the data, we prove that the problem admits a unique global smooth solution and study its asymptotics.

title: Some hemivariational inequalities in the Euclidean space
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to study the existence of weak solutions for some classes of hemivariational problems in the Euclidean space $\mathbb{R}^d$ ($d\geq 3$). These hemivariational inequalities have a variational structure and, thanks to this, we are able to find a non-trivial weak solution for them by using variational methods and a non-smooth version of the Palais principle of symmetric criticality for locally Lipschitz continuous functionals, due to Krawcewicz and Marzantowicz. The main tools in our approach are based on appropriate theoretical arguments on suitable subgroups of the orthogonal group $O(d)$ and their actions on the Sobolev space $H^1(\mathbb{R}^d)$. Moreover, under an additional hypotheses on the dimension $d$ and in the presence of symmetry on the nonlinear datum, the existence of multiple pairs of sign-changing solutions with different symmetries structure has been proved. In connection to classical Schr\"{o}dinger equations a concrete and meaningful example of an application is presented.

title: A-priori bounds for quasilinear problems in critical dimension
abstract: Abstract We establish uniform a-priori bounds for solutions of the quasilinear problems $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \begin{cases} -{\it\Delta}_Nu=f(u)\quad&\mbox{in }{\it\Omega},\\ u=0\quad&\mbox{on }{\partial{\it\Omega}}, \end{cases} \end{array}$$ where Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù N is a bounded smooth convex domain and f is positive, superlinear and subcritical in the sense of the Trudinger-Moser inequality. The typical growth of f is thus exponential. Finally, a generalisation of the result for nonhomogeneous nonlinearities is given. Using a blow-up approach, this paper completes the results in [1, 2], extending the class of nonlinearities for which the uniform a-priori bound applies.

title: Positive solutions for diffusive Logistic equation with refuge
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we study the stationary solutions of the Logistic equation $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle u_t=\mathcal {D}[u]+\lambda u-[b(x)+\varepsilon]u^p \text{ in }{\it\Omega} \end{array}$$ with Dirichlet boundary condition, here ùìì is a diffusion operator and Œµ > 0, p > 1. The weight function b ( x ) is nonnegative and vanishes in a smooth subdomain Œ© 0 of Œ© . We investigate the asymptotic profiles of positive stationary solutions with the critical value Œª when Œµ is sufficiently small. We find that the profiles are different between nonlocal and classical diffusion equations.

title: Bifurcation of time-periodic solutions for the incompressible flow of nematic liquid crystals in three dimension
authors: Hengyan Li; Xin Zhao; Weiping Yan
abstract: Abstract This paper is devoted to the study of the dynamical behavior for the 3D incompressible flow of liquid crystals. We prove that this system under smooth external forces possesses time dependent periodic solutions, bifurcating from a steady solution.

title: On isolated singularities of Kirchhoff equations

title: Regularity for commutators of the local multilinear fractional maximal operators
abstract: Abstract In this paper we introduce and study the commutators of the local multilinear fractional maximal operators and a vector-valued function b‚Éó = ( b 1 , ‚Ä¶, b m ). Under the condition that each b i belongs to the first order Sobolev spaces, the bounds for the above commutators are established on the first order Sobolev spaces.

title: On some elliptic interface problems with nonhomogeneous jump conditions
abstract: We obtain nontrivial solutions of some elliptic interface problems with nonhomogeneous jump conditions that arise in localized chemical reactions and nonlinear neutral inclusions. Our proofs in bounded domains use Morse theoretical arguments, in particular, critical group computations. An extension to the whole space is proved using concentration compactness arguments.

title: A refined bound on the dimension of ‚Ñù N for an elliptic system involving critical terms with infinitely many solutions
authors: Samira Benmouloud; Mustapha Khiddi; Simohammed Sba√Ø
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we extend the result of Yan and Yang [16] on equations to an elliptic system involving critical Sobolev and Hardy‚ÄìSobolev exponents in bounded domains satisfying some geometric condition. In addition, we weaken the conditions on the dimension N and on the potential <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>a</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {a(x)} set in [16]. Our main result asserts, by a variational global-compactness argument, that the condition on the dimension N can be refined from <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>7</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N\geq 7} to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>max</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å°</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mn>4</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚åä</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>s</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>‚åã</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {N>\max(4,\lfloor 2s\rfloor+2)} , where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {0<s<2} and still end up with infinitely many solutions.

title: Front instability in a condensed phase combustion model
authors: Alexis Bonnet; Fathi Dkhil; Elisabeth Logak
abstract: Abstract We consider a condensed phase (or solid) combustion model and its linearization around the travelling front solution. We construct an Evans function to characterize the eigenvalues of the linearized problem. We estimate this functional in the high activation energy limit. We deduce the existence of zeros with nonnegative real part for high activation energy, which proves the linear instability of the travelling front solution.

title: A remark on bifurcation of Fredholm maps
abstract: Abstract We modify an argument for multiparameter bifurcation of Fredholm maps by Fitzpatrick and Pejsachowicz to strengthen results on the topology of the bifurcation set. Furthermore, we discuss an application to families of differential equations parametrised by Grassmannians.

title: Comparison and maximum principles for a class of flux-limited diffusions with external force fields
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we are interested in a general equation that has finite speed of propagation compatible with Einstein's theory of special relativity. This equation without external force fields has been derived recently by means of optimal transportation theory. We first provide an argument to incorporate the external force fields. Then, we are concerned with comparison and maximum principles for this equation. We consider both stationary and evolutionary problems. We show that the former satisfies a comparison principle and a strong maximum principle while the latter fulfils weaker ones. The key technique is a transformation that matches well with the gradient flow structure of the equation.

title: On the well-posedness of global fully nonlinear first order elliptic systems
abstract: Abstract In the very recent paper [15], the second author proved that for any <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>L</m:mi> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {f\in L^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{n},\mathbb{R}^{N})} , the fully nonlinear first order system <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>F</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>D</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>f</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {F(\,\cdot\,,\mathrm{D}u)=f} is well posed in the so-called J. L. Lions space and, moreover, the unique strong solution <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>:</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {u\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{N}} to the problem satisfies a quantitative estimate. A central ingredient in the proof was the introduction of an appropriate notion of ellipticity for F inspired by Campanato‚Äôs classical work in the 2nd order case. Herein, we extend the results of [15] by introducing a new strictly weaker ellipticity condition and by proving well-posedness in the same ‚Äúenergy‚Äù space.

title: Prescribed singularities with weights
abstract: of maps with prescribed singularities, where is a continuous positive weight. Our result extends previous ones of H. Brezis, J.-M. Coron and E. H. Lieb (1986), G. Alberti, S. Baldo and G. Orlandi (2003), and V. Millot (2005).

title: Non-stationary Navier‚ÄìStokes equations in 2D power cusp domain
abstract: Abstract The initial boundary value problem for the non-stationary Navier-Stokes equations is studied in 2D bounded domain with a power cusp singular point O on the boundary. We consider the case where the boundary value has a nonzero flux over the boundary. In this case there is a source/sink in O and the solution necessary has infinite energy integral. In the first part of the paper the formal asymptotic expansion of the solution near the singular point was constructed. In this, second part, the constructed asymptotic decomposition is justified, i.e., existence of the solution which is represented as the sum of the constructed asymptotic expansion and a term with finite energy norm is proved. Moreover, it is proved that the solution represented in this form is unique.

title: On the set of positive solutions for resonant Robin (p,q)-equations
abstract: Abstract We consider a nonlinear Robin problem driven by the ( p , q )-Laplacian and a parametric reaction exhibiting the competition of a concave term and of a resonant perturbation. We prove a bifurcation-type theorem describing the changes in the set of positive solutions as the parameter Œª moves on ‚ÑùÃä + = (0, +‚àû). Also, we determine the continuity properties of the solution multifunction.

title: Lane-Emden equations perturbed by nonhomogeneous potential in the super critical case
authors: Yong Ma; Ying Wang; C√©sar E. Torres Ledesma
abstract: Abstract Our purpose of this paper is to study positive solutions of Lane-Emden equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"> <m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi class="MJX-tex-mathit" mathvariant="italic">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>V</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mspace width="1em" /> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">i</m:mi> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">n</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mspace width="1em" /> <m:msup> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:msup> <m:mo class="MJX-variant">‚àñ</m:mo> <m:mo fence="false" stretchy="false">{</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo fence="false" stretchy="false">}</m:mo> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:math> $$\begin{array}{} -{\it\Delta} u = V u^p\quad {\rm in}\quad \mathbb{R}^N\setminus\{0\} \end{array}$$ (0.1) perturbed by a non-homogeneous potential V when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mo stretchy="false">[</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mi>c</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:math> $\begin{array}{} p\in [p_c, \frac{N+2}{N-2}), \end{array}$ where p c is the Joseph-Ludgren exponent. When <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mi>c</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:math> $\begin{array}{} p\in (\frac{N}{N-2}, p_c), \end{array}$ the fast decaying solution could be approached by super and sub solutions, which are constructed by the stability of the k -fast decaying solution w k of ‚àí Œî u = u p in ‚Ñù N ‚àñ {0} by authors in [9]. While the fast decaying solution w k is unstable for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mi>c</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> <m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo> <m:mo>,</m:mo> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:math> $\begin{array}{} p\in (p_c, \frac{N+2}{N-2}), \end{array}$ so these fast decaying solutions seem not able to disturbed like (0.1) by non-homogeneous potential V . A surprising observation that there exists a bounded sub solution of (0.1) from the extremal solution of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi class="MJX-tex-mathit" mathvariant="italic">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:math> $\begin{array}{} -{\it\Delta} u = u^{\frac{N+2}{N-2}} \end{array}$ in ‚Ñù N and then a sequence of fast decaying solutions and slow decaying solutions could be derived under appropriated restrictions for V .

title: Variation inequalities for rough singular integrals and their commutators on Morrey spaces and Besov spaces
authors: Xiao Zhang; Feng Liu; Huiyun Zhang
abstract: Abstract This paper is devoted to investigating the boundedness, continuity and compactness for variation operators of singular integrals and their commutators on Morrey spaces and Besov spaces. More precisely, we establish the boundedness for the variation operators of singular integrals with rough kernels Œ© ‚àà L q (S n ‚àí1 ) ( q > 1) and their commutators on Morrey spaces as well as the compactness for the above commutators on Lebesgue spaces and Morrey spaces. In addition, we present a criterion on the boundedness and continuity for a class of variation operators of singular integrals and their commutators on Besov spaces. As applications, we obtain the boundedness and continuity for the variation operators of Hilbert transform, Hermit Riesz transform, Riesz transforms and rough singular integrals as well as their commutators on Besov spaces.

title: Refined second boundary behavior of the unique strictly convex solution to a singular Monge-Amp√®re equation
authors: Haitao Wan; Yongxiu Shi; Wei Liu
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we establish the second boundary behavior of the unique strictly convex solution to a singular Dirichlet problem for the Monge-Amp√®re equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><m:mtext> det</m:mtext><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:msup><m:mi>D</m:mi><m:mrow><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow></m:msup><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mi>b</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mi>g</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:mspace width="thinmathspace" /><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo><</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mtext> in </m:mtext><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi><m:mtext> and </m:mtext><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mtext> on </m:mtext><m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àÇ</m:mi><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi><m:mo>,</m:mo></m:math> $$\mbox{ det}(D^{2} u)=b(x)g(-u),\,u<0 \mbox{ in }\Omega \mbox{ and } u=0 \mbox{ on }\partial\Omega, $$ where Œ© is a bounded, smooth and strictly convex domain in ‚Ñù N ( N ‚â• 2), b ‚àà C ‚àû (Œ©) is positive and may be singular (including critical singular) or vanish on the boundary, g ‚àà C 1 ((0, ‚àû), (0, ‚àû)) is decreasing on (0, ‚àû) with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:munder><m:mo>lim</m:mo><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">‚Üí</m:mo><m:msup><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"><m:mo>+</m:mo></m:mrow></m:msup></m:mrow></m:munder><m:mi>g</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>t</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi></m:math> $ \lim\limits_{t\rightarrow0^{+}}g(t)=\infty $ and g is normalized regularly varying at zero with index ‚àí Œ≥ ( Œ≥ >1). Our results reveal the refined influence of the highest and the lowest values of the ( N ‚àí 1)-th curvature on the second boundary behavior of the unique strictly convex solution to the problem.

title: On the uniqueness for weak solutions of steady double-phase fluids
authors: Mohamed Abdelwahed; Luigi C. Berselli; Nejmeddine Chorfi
abstract: Abstract We consider a double-phase non-Newtonian fluid, described by a stress tensor which is the sum of a p -Stokes and a q -Stokes stress tensor, with 1 < p <2 < q <‚àû. For a wide range of parameters ( p , q ), we prove the uniqueness of small solutions. We use the p < 2 features to obtain quadratic-type estimates for the stress-tensor, while we use the improved regularity coming from the term with q > 2 to justify calculations for weak solutions. Results are obtained through a careful use of the symmetries of the convective term and are also valid for rather general (even anisotropic) stress-tensors.

title: Compact Sobolev-Slobodeckij embeddings and positive solutions to fractional Laplacian equations
abstract: Abstract In this work, we study the existence of a positive solution to an elliptic equation involving the fractional Laplacian (‚àí Œî ) s in ‚Ñù n , for n ‚â• 2, such as (0.1) <m:math $$(-\Delta)^{s} u+E(x) u+V(x) u^{q-1}=K(x) f(u)+u^{2_{s}^{\star}-1}.$$ Here, s ‚àà (0, 1), <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>q</m:mi><m:mo>‚àà</m:mo><m:mfenced open="[" \in\left[2,2_{s}^{\star}\right)$ with <m:math $2_{s}^{\star}:=\frac{2 n}{n-2 s}$ being the fractional critical Sobolev exponent, E ( x ), K ( x ), V ( x ) > 0 : ‚Ñù n ‚Üí ‚Ñù are measurable functions which satisfy joint ‚Äúvanishing at infinity‚Äù conditions in a measure-theoretic sense, and f ( u ) is a continuous function on ‚Ñù of quasi-critical, super- q -linear growth with f ( u ) ‚â• 0 if u ‚â• 0. Besides, we study the existence of multiple positive solutions to an elliptic equation in ‚Ñù n such as (0.2) <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>s</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup></m:mrow><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>E</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>V</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:msup><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mrow><m:mi>q</m:mi><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow></m:msup><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mi>Œª</m:mi><m:mi>K</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">(</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo stretchy="false">)</m:mo><m:msup><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mrow><m:mi>r</m:mi><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow></m:msup><m:mo>,</m:mo></m:math> $$(-\Delta)^{s} u+E(x) u+V(x) u^{q-1}=\lambda K(x) u^{r-1},$$ where 2 < r < q < ‚àû(both possibly (super-)critical), E ( x ), K ( x ), V ( x ) > 0 : ‚Ñù n ‚Üí ‚Ñù are measurable functions satisfying joint integrability conditions, and Œª > 0 is a parameter. To study (0.1)-(0.2), we first describe a family of general fractional Sobolev-Slobodeckij spaces M s ; q , p (‚Ñù n ) as well as their associated compact embedding results.

title: New solutions for critical Neumann problems in ‚Ñù2
abstract: Abstract We consider the elliptic equation {-\Delta u+u=0} in a bounded, smooth domain Œ© in {\mathbb{R}^{2}} subject to the nonlinear Neumann boundary condition {\frac{\partial u}{\partial\nu}=\lambda ue^{u^{2}}} , where ŒΩ denotes the outer normal vector of {\partial\Omega} . Here {\lambda>0} is a small parameter. For any Œª small we construct positive solutions concentrating, as {\lambda\to 0} , around points of the boundary of Œ©.

title: A constructive method for convex solutions of a class of nonlinear Black-Scholes equations
authors: Mostafa Abounouh; Hassan Al Moatassime; A√Øcha Driouch; Olivier Goubet
abstract: Abstract In this work, we are concerned with the theoretical study of a nonlinear Black-Scholes equation resulting from market frictions. We will focus our attention on Barles and Soner‚Äôs model where the volatility is enlarged due to the presence of transaction costs. The aim of this paper is to give a constructive mathematical approach for proving the existence of convex solutions to a non degenerate fully nonlinear deterministic problem with nonlinear dependence upon the highest derivative. The existence of a strong solution to the original equation is shown by considering a monotone sequence satisfying an abstract Barenblatt equation and converging toward the solution of a limit problem.

title: Bifurcations of nontrivial solutions of a cubic Helmholtz system
abstract: Abstract This paper presents local and global bifurcation results for radially symmetric solutions of the cubic Helmholtz system $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \begin{cases} -{\it\Delta} u - \mu u = \left( u^2 + b \: v^2 \right) u &\text{ on } \mathbb{R}^3, \\ -{\it\Delta} v - \nu v = \left( v^2 + b \: u^2 \right) v &\text{ on } \mathbb{R}^3. \end{cases} \end{array}$$ It is shown that every point along any given branch of radial semitrivial solutions ( u 0 , 0, b ) or diagonal solutions ( u b , u b , b ) (for Œº = ŒΩ ) is a bifurcation point. Our analysis is based on a detailed investigation of the oscillatory behavior and the decay of solutions at infinity.

title: The superposition operator in the space of functions continuous and converging at infinity on the real half-axis
abstract: Abstract We will consider the so-called superposition operator in the space CC (‚Ñù + ) of real functions defined, continuous on the real half-axis ‚Ñù + and converging to finite limits at infinity. We will assume that the function f = f ( t , x ) generating the mentioned superposition operator is locally uniformly continuous with respect to the variable x uniformly for t ‚àà ‚Ñù + . Moreover, we require that the function t ‚Üí f ( t , x ) satisfies the Cauchy condition at infinity uniformly with respect to the variable x . Under the above indicated assumptions a few properties of the superposition operator in question are derived. Examples illustrating our considerations will be included.

title: Global gradient estimates for Dirichlet problems of elliptic operators with a BMO antisymmetric part
authors: Sibei Yang; Dachun Yang; Wen Yuan
abstract: Abstract Let <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>n</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â•</m:mo> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:math> n\ge 2 and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>‚äÇ</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> \Omega \subset {{\mathbb{R}}}^{n} be a bounded nontangentially accessible domain. In this article, the authors investigate (weighted) global gradient estimates for Dirichlet boundary value problems of second-order elliptic equations of divergence form with an elliptic symmetric part and a BMO antisymmetric part in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi> </m:math> \Omega . More precisely, for any given <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\in \left(2,\infty ) , the authors prove that a weak reverse H√∂lder inequality with exponent <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:math> p implies the global <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {W}^{1,p} estimate and the global weighted <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>W</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {W}^{1,q} estimate, with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>q</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>[</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>]</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> q\in \left[2,p] and some Muckenhoupt weights, of solutions to Dirichlet boundary value problems. As applications, the authors establish some global gradient estimates for solutions to Dirichlet boundary value problems of second-order elliptic equations of divergence form with small <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">BMO</m:mi> </m:math> {\rm{BMO}} symmetric part and small <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">BMO</m:mi> </m:math> {\rm{BMO}} antisymmetric part, respectively, on bounded Lipschitz domains, quasi-convex domains, Reifenberg flat domains, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{1} domains, or (semi-)convex domains, in weighted Lebesgue spaces. Furthermore, as further applications, the authors obtain the global gradient estimate, respectively, in (weighted) Lorentz spaces, (Lorentz‚Äì)Morrey spaces, (Musielak‚Äì)Orlicz spaces, and variable Lebesgue spaces. Even on global gradient estimates in Lebesgue spaces, the results obtained in this article improve the known results via weakening the assumption on the coefficient matrix.

title: Constrained optimization problems governed by PDE models of grain boundary motions
authors: Harbir Antil; Shodai Kubota; Ken Shirakawa; Noriaki Yamazaki
abstract: Abstract In this article, we consider a class of optimal control problems governed by state equations of Kobayashi-Warren-Carter-type. The control is given by physical temperature. The focus is on problems in dimensions less than or equal to 4. The results are divided into four Main Theorems, concerned with: solvability and parameter dependence of state equations and optimal control problems; the first-order necessary optimality conditions for these regularized optimal control problems. Subsequently, we derive the limiting systems and optimality conditions and study their well-posedness.

title: On the nonlinear perturbations of self-adjoint operators
authors: Micha≈Ç Be≈Çdzi≈Ñski; Marek Galewski; Witold Majdak
abstract: Abstract Using elements of the theory of linear operators in Hilbert spaces and monotonicity tools we obtain the existence and uniqueness results for a wide class of nonlinear problems driven by the equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>T</m:mi> <m:mi>x</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>N</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> Tx=N\left(x) , where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>T</m:mi> </m:math> T is a self-adjoint operator in a real Hilbert space <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi class="MJX-tex-caligraphic" mathvariant="script">‚Ñã</m:mi> </m:math> {\mathcal{ {\mathcal H} }} and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>N</m:mi> </m:math> N is a nonlinear perturbation. Both potential and nonpotential perturbations are considered. This approach is an extension of the results known for elliptic operators.

title: On sufficient ‚Äúlocal‚Äù conditions for existence results to generalized p(.)-Laplace equations involving critical growth
abstract: Abstract In this article, we study the existence of multiple solutions to a generalized <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(\cdot ) -Laplace equation with two parameters involving critical growth. More precisely, we give sufficient ‚Äúlocal‚Äù conditions, which mean that growths between the main operator and nonlinear term are locally assumed for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(\cdot ) -sublinear, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(\cdot ) -superlinear, and sandwich-type cases. Compared to constant exponent problems (e.g., <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:math> p -Laplacian and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>q</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> \left(p,q) -Laplacian), this characterizes the study of variable exponent problems. We show this by applying variants of the mountain pass theorem for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(\cdot ) -sublinear and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚ãÖ</m:mo> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> p\left(\cdot ) -superlinear cases and constructing critical values defined by a minimax argument in the genus theory for sandwich-type case. Moreover, we also obtain a nontrivial nonnegative solution for sandwich-type case changing the role of parameters. Our work is a generalization of several existing works in the literature.

title: Standing wave solution for the generalized Jackiw-Pi model
authors: Hyungjin Huh; Yuanfeng Jin; You-Wei Ma; Guanghui Jin
abstract: Abstract We study the existence and nonexistence of the standing wave solution for the generalized Jackiw-Pi model by using variational method. Depending on interaction strength <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:math> \lambda , we have three different situations. The existence and nonexistence of the standing wave solution correspond to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mn>1</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:math> 1\lt \lambda and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> 0\lt \lambda \lt 1 , respectively. We have the explicit solution of self-dual equation for the borderline <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:math> \lambda =1 .

title: Bautin bifurcation with additive noise
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider stochastic dynamics of a two-dimensional stochastic differential equation with additive noise. When the strength of the noise is zero, this equation undergoes a Bautin bifurcation. We obtain the main conclusions including the existence and uniqueness of the solution, synchronization of system and property of the random equilibrium, where going through some processes like deducing the stationary probability density of the equation and calculating the Lyapunov exponent. For better understanding of the effect under noise, we make a clear comparison between the stochastic system and the deterministic one and make precise numerical simulations to show the slight changes at Bautin bifurcation point. Furthermore, we take a real model as an example to present the application of our theoretical results.

title: Small solitons and multisolitons in the generalized Davey-Stewartson system
authors: Mengxue Bai; Jian Zhang; Shihui Zhu
abstract: Abstract By introducing and solving a new cross-constrained variational problem, a one-to-one correspondence from the prescribed mass to frequency of soliton is established for the generalized Davey-Stewartson system in two-dimensional space. Orbital stability of small soiltons depending on frequencies is proved. Multisolitons with different speeds are constructed by stable small solitons.

title: Uniqueness of solutions to singular p-Laplacian equations with subcritical nonlinearity
abstract: Abstract We present a geometric approach to the study of quasilinear elliptic p -Laplacian problems on a ball in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:msup> </m:math> ${\mathbb{R}^{n}}$ using techniques from dynamical systems. These techniques include a study of the invariant manifolds that arise from the union of the solutions to the elliptic PDE in phase space, as well as variational computations on two vector fields tangent to the invariant manifolds. We show that for a certain class of nonlinearities f with subcritical growth relative to the Sobolev critical exponent <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mi>p</m:mi> <m:mo>*</m:mo> </m:msup> </m:math> ${p^{*}}$ , there can be at most one such solution satisfying <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>Œî</m:mi> <m:mi>p</m:mi> </m:msub> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>f</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> ${\Delta_{p}u+f(u)=0}$ on a ball with Dirichlet boundary conditions.

title: Moduli of continuity, functional spaces,\break and elliptic boundary value problems. The full regularity spaces C Œ± 0,Œª(Œ©ÃÖ)
abstract: Abstract Let <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>ùë≥</m:mi> </m:math> {\boldsymbol{L}} be a second order uniformly elliptic operator, and consider the equation <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>ùë≥</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mi>u</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mi>f</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\boldsymbol{L}u=f} under the boundary condition <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>u</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {u=0} . We assume data f in generical subspaces of continuous functions <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>D</m:mi> <m:mover> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> </m:msub> </m:math> {D_{\overline{\omega}}} characterized by a given modulus of continuity <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mover> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mi>r</m:mi> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\overline{\omega}(r)} , and show that the second order derivatives of the solution u belong to functional spaces <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msub> <m:mi>D</m:mi> <m:mover> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>^</m:mo> </m:mover> </m:msub> </m:math> {D_{\widehat{\omega}}} , characterized by a modulus of continuity <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mover> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>^</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mi>r</m:mi> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\widehat{\omega}(r)} expressed in terms of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mover> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mi>r</m:mi> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\overline{\omega}(r)} . Results are optimal. In some cases, as for H√∂lder spaces, <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msub> <m:mi>D</m:mi> <m:mover> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>^</m:mo> </m:mover> </m:msub> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:msub> <m:mi>D</m:mi> <m:mover> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> </m:msub> </m:mrow> </m:math> {D_{\widehat{\omega}}=D_{\overline{\omega}}} . In this case we say that full regularity occurs. In particular, full regularity occurs for the new class of functional spaces <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>C</m:mi> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mover> <m:mi>Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {C^{0,\lambda}_{\alpha}(\overline{\Omega})} which includes, as a particular case, the classical H√∂lder spaces <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:msup> <m:mi>C</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mover> <m:mi>Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:msubsup> <m:mi>C</m:mi> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>Œª</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> <m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mover> <m:mi>Œ©</m:mi> <m:mo>¬Ø</m:mo> </m:mover> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> </m:math> {C^{0,\lambda}(\overline{\Omega})=C^{0,\lambda}_{0}(\overline{\Omega})} . Few words, concerning the possibility of generalizations and applications to non-linear problems, are expended at the end of the introduction and also in the last section.

title: Concentrating solutions for a planar elliptic problem with large nonlinear exponent and Robin boundary condition
abstract: Abstract Let Œ© ‚äÇ ‚Ñù 2 be a bounded domain with smooth boundary and b ( x ) > 0 a smooth function defined on ‚àÇŒ© . We study the following Robin boundary value problem: $$\begin{array}{} \displaystyle \left\{ \begin{alignedat}{2} &{\it\Delta} u+u^p=0 &\quad& \text{in }{\it\Omega},\\ &u>0 &\quad& \text{in }{\it\Omega},\\ &\frac{\partial u}{\partial\nu} +\lambda b(x)u=0 &\quad& \text{on } \partial{\it\Omega}, \end{alignedat} \right. \end{array}$$ where ŒΩ denotes the exterior unit vector normal to ‚àÇŒ© , 0 < Œª < +‚àû and p > 1 is a large exponent. We construct solutions of this problem which exhibit concentration as p ‚Üí +‚àû and simultaneously as Œª ‚Üí +‚àû at points that get close to the boundary, and show that in general the set of solutions of this problem exhibits a richer structure than the problem with Dirichlet boundary condition.

title: Infinitely many solutions for non-local problems with broken symmetry
authors: Rossella Bartolo; Pablo L. De N√°poli; Addolorata Salvatore
abstract: Abstract The aim of this paper is to investigate the existence of solutions of the non-local elliptic problem <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>{</m:mo> \left\{\begin{aligned} &\displaystyle(-\Delta)^{s}u\ =\lvert u\rvert^{p-2}u+h(% x)&&\displaystyle\text{in }\Omega,\\ &\displaystyle{u=0}&&\displaystyle\text{on }\mathbb{R}^{n}\setminus\Omega,\end% {aligned}\right. where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>s</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> This problem requires the study of the eigenvalue problem related to the fractional Laplace operator, with or without potential.

title: Borsuk‚Äôs antipodal fixed points theorems for compact or condensing set-valued maps
authors: Najla Altwaijry; Souhail Chebbi; Hakim Hammami; Pascal Gourdel
abstract: Abstract We give a generalized version of the well-known Borsuk‚Äôs antipodal fixed point theorem for a large class of antipodally approachable condensing or compact set-valued maps defined on closed subsets of locally convex topological vector spaces. These results contain corresponding results obtained in the literature for compact set-valued maps with convex values.

title: Existence via regularity of solutions for elliptic systems and saddle points of functionals of the calculus of variations
abstract:

title: Weighted Caffarelli‚ÄìKohn‚ÄìNirenberg type inequalities related to Grushin type operators
abstract: Abstract We consider the Grushin type operator on <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:msubsup><m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mi>d</m:mi></m:msubsup><m:mo>√ó</m:mo><m:msubsup><m:mi>‚Ñù</m:mi><m:mi>y</m:mi><m:mi>k</m:mi></m:msubsup></m:mrow></m:math> {\mathbb{R}^{d}_{x}\times\mathbb{R}^{k}_{y}} of the form <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:msub><m:mi>G</m:mi><m:mi>Œº</m:mi></m:msub><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:munderover><m:mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">‚àë</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mi>d</m:mi></m:munderover><m:msubsup><m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo><m:msub><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mi>i</m:mi></m:msub><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:msubsup></m:mrow><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:munderover><m:mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">‚àë</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mi>d</m:mi></m:munderover><m:msubsup><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mi>i</m:mi><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:msubsup></m:mrow><m:mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mn>2</m:mn><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi>Œº</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup><m:mo>‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mrow><m:munderover><m:mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">‚àë</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>j</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mi>k</m:mi></m:munderover><m:msubsup><m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo><m:msub><m:mi>y</m:mi><m:mi>j</m:mi></m:msub><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:msubsup></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:mrow></m:math> G_{\mu}=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\partial_{x_{i}}^{2}+\Bigl{(}\sum_{i=1}^{d}x_{i}^{2}% \Bigr{)}^{2\mu}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\partial_{y_{j}}^{2} and derive weighted Hardy‚ÄìSobolev type inequalities and weighted Caffarelli‚ÄìKohn‚ÄìNirenberg type inequalities related to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msub><m:mi>G</m:mi><m:mi>Œº</m:mi></m:msub></m:math> {G_{\mu}} .

title: Sign-changing two-peak solutions for an elliptic free boundary problem related to confined plasmas
abstract: Abstract By a perturbative argument, we construct solutions for a plasma-type problem with two opposite-signed sharp peaks at levels 1 and <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mo>-</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:math> {-\gamma} , respectively, where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:math> {0<\gamma<1} . We establish some physically relevant qualitative properties for such solutions, including the connectedness of the level sets and the asymptotic location of the peaks as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ≥</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>+</m:mo> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:math> {\gamma\to 0^{+}} .

title: Nonlinear elliptic‚Äìparabolic problem involving p-Dirichlet-to-Neumann operator with critical exponent
authors: Yanhua Deng; Zhong Tan; Minghong Xie
abstract: Abstract We consider the nonlinear elliptic‚Äìparabolic boundary value problem involving the Dirichlet-to-Neumann operator of p-Laplace type at the critical Sobolev exponent. We first obtain the existence and asymptotic estimates of the global solution, and the sufficient conditions of finite time blowup of the solution by using the energy method. Second, we improve the regularity of solution by Moser-type iteration. Finally, we analyze the long-time asymptotic behavior of the global solution. Moreover, with the help of the concentration compactness principle, we present a precise description of the concentration phenomenon of the solution in the forward time infinity.

title: On a system of multi-component Ginzburg-Landau vortices
authors: Rejeb Hadiji; Jongmin Han; Juhee Sohn
abstract: Abstract We study the asymptotic behavior of solutions for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>n</m:mi> </m:math> n -component Ginzburg-Landau equations as <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œµ</m:mi> <m:mo>‚Üí</m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> </m:math> \varepsilon \to 0 . We prove that the minimizers converge locally in any <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mi>k</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {C}^{k} -norm to a solution of a system of generalized harmonic map equations.

title: Dirichlet problems involving the Hardy-Leray operators with multiple polars
abstract:
Abstract Our aim of this article is to study qualitative properties of Dirichlet problems involving the Hardy-Leray operator <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi class="MJX-tex-caligraphic" mathvariant="script">‚Ñí</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>V</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub><m:mo>‚âî</m:mo><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mi>V</m:mi></m:math> {{\mathcal{ {\mathcal L} }}}_{V}:= -\Delta +V , where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>V</m:mi><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>x</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:msubsup><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mo>‚àë</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msubsup><m:mfrac><m:mrow><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi>Œº</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mo>‚à£</m:mo><m:mi>x</m:mi><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi>A</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub><m:mo>‚à£</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow></m:msup></m:mrow></m:mfrac></m:math> V\left(x)={\sum }_{i=1}^{m} rac{{\mu }_{i}}{{| x-{A}_{i}| }^{2}} , with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi>Œº</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub><m:mo>‚â•</m:mo><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mfrac><m:mrow><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi><m:mo>‚àí</m:mo><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow></m:msup></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mn>4</m:mn></m:mrow></m:mfrac></m:math> {\mu }_{i}\ge - rac{{\left(N-2)}^{2}}{4} being the Hardy-Leray potential containing the polars‚Äô set <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi class="MJX-tex-caligraphic" mathvariant="script">A</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>{</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi>A</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub><m:mo>:</m:mo><m:mi>i</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mo>‚Ä¶</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>}</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> {{\mathcal{A}}}_{m}=\left\{{A}_{i}:i=1,\ldots ,might\} in <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">R</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup></m:math> {{\mathbb{R}}}^{N} ( <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>N</m:mi><m:mo>‚â•</m:mo><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:math> N\ge 2 ). Since the inverse-square potentials are critical with respect to the Laplacian operator, the coefficients <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msubsup><m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mo>{</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi>Œº</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub></m:mrow><m:mo>}</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>1</m:mn></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msubsup></m:math> {\left\{{\mu }_{i}ight\}}_{i=1}^{m} and the locations of polars <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mrow><m:mo>{</m:mo><m:mrow><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi>A</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>i</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub></m:mrow><m:mo>}</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> \left\{{A}_{i}ight\} play an important role in the properties of solutions to the related Poisson problems subject to zero Dirichlet boundary conditions. Let <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi></m:math> \Omega be a bounded domain containing <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi class="MJX-tex-caligraphic" mathvariant="script">A</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>m</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub></m:math> {{\mathcal{A}}}_{m} . When the spectral does not contain the origin, we then consider the weak solutions of the Poisson problem <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi>E</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow><m:mspace width="1.0em"/><m:mspace width="1.0em"/><m:msub><m:mrow><m:mi class="MJX-tex-caligraphic" mathvariant="script">‚Ñí</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>V</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msub><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mi>ŒΩ</m:mi><m:mspace width="1em"/><m:mi mathvariant="normal">in</m:mi><m:mspace width="0.33em"/><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi><m:mo>,</m:mo><m:mspace width="1.0em"/><m:mi>u</m:mi><m:mo>=</m:mo><m:mn>0</m:mn><m:mspace width="1em"/><m:mi mathvariant="normal">on</m:mi><m:mspace width="0.33em"/><m:mo>‚àÇ</m:mo><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi><m:mo>,</m:mo></m:math> \left(E)\hspace{1.0em}\hspace{1.0em}{{\mathcal{ {\mathcal L} }}}_{V}u=
u \hspace{1em}{m{in}}\hspace{0.33em}\Omega ,\hspace{1.0em}u=0\hspace{1em}{m{on}}\hspace{0.33em}\partial \Omega , when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>ŒΩ</m:mi></m:math> 
u belongs to <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi>L</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>p</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup><m:mrow><m:mo>(</m:mo><m:mrow><m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œ©</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo>)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:math> {L}^{p}\left(\Omega ) , with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>p</m:mi><m:mo>></m:mo><m:mfrac><m:mrow><m:mn>2</m:mn><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi><m:mo>+</m:mo><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow></m:mfrac></m:math> p\gt  rac{2N}{N+2} in the variational framework, and we obtain a global weighted <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:msup><m:mrow><m:mi>L</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mi>‚àû</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup></m:math> {L}^{\infty } estimate when <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><m:mi>p</m:mi><m:mo>></m:mo><m:mfrac><m:mrow><m:mi>N</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mrow><m:mn>2</m:mn></m:mrow></m:mfrac></m:math> p\gt  rac{N}{2} . title: On the topological gradient method for an inverse problem resolution
abstract: Abstract In this work, we consider the topological gradient method to deal with an inverse problem associated with three-dimensional Stokes equations. The problem consists in detecting unknown point forces acting on fluid from measurements on the boundary of the domain. We present an asymptotic expansion of the considered cost function using the topological sensitivity analysis method. A detection algorithm is then presented using the developed formula. Some numerical tests are presented to show the efficiency of the presented algorithm.

title: Uniform complex time heat Kernel estimates without Gaussian bounds
abstract: Abstract The aim of this article is twofold. First, we study the uniform complex time heat kernel estimates of <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi>e</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi>z</m:mi> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> {e}^{-z{\left(-\Delta )}^{\frac{\alpha }{2}}} for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> <m:mo>></m:mo> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>z</m:mi> <m:mo>‚àà</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mi mathvariant="double-struck">C</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>+</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:msup> </m:math> \alpha \gt 0,z\in {{\mathbb{C}}}^{+} . To this end, we establish the asymptotic estimates for <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>P</m:mi> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mi>z</m:mi> <m:mo>,</m:mo> <m:mi>x</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:math> P\left(z,x) with <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>z</m:mi> </m:math> z satisfying <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mn>0</m:mn> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mi>œâ</m:mi> <m:mo>‚â§</m:mo> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> <m:mi>Œ∏</m:mi> <m:mo>‚à£</m:mo> <m:mo><</m:mo> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>œÄ</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:math> 0\lt \omega \le | \theta | \lt \frac{\pi }{2} followed by the uniform complex time heat kernel estimates. Second, we studied the uniform complex time estimates of the analytic semigroup generated by <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>H</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mo>(</m:mo> <m:mrow> <m:mo>‚àí</m:mo> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">Œî</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mo>)</m:mo> </m:mrow> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mstyle displaystyle="false"> <m:mfrac> <m:mrow> <m:mi>Œ±</m:mi> </m:mrow> <m:mrow> <m:mn>2</m:mn> </m:mrow> </m:mfrac> </m:mstyle> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mo>+</m:mo> <m:mi>V</m:mi> </m:math> H={\left(-\Delta )}^{\tfrac{\alpha }{2}}+V , where <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mi>V</m:mi> </m:math> V belongs to higher-order Kato class.

title: Erratum: On the positive, ‚Äúradial‚Äù solutions of a semilinear elliptic equation in ‚ÑçN [Adv. Nonlinear Anal. 1 (2012), no. 1, 1‚Äì25]
Isoperimetric inequalities for -Hessian equations
authors: Ahmed Mohammed; Giovanni Porru; Abdessalam Safoui
abstract: We consider the homogeneous Dirichlet problem for a special -Hessian equation of sub-linear type in a -convex domain , . We study the comparison between the solution of this problem and the (radial) solution of the corresponding problem in a ball having the same -quermassintegral as . Next, we consider the eigenvalue problem for the -Hessian equation and study a comparison between its principal eigenfunction and the principal eigenfunction of the corresponding problem in a ball having the same -quermassintegral as . Symmetrization techniques and comparison principles are the main tools used to get these inequalities.

title: Fixed point of some Markov operator of Frobenius-Perron type generated by a random family of point-transformations in ‚Ñù d
authors: Peter Bugiel; Stanis≈Çaw Wƒôdrychowicz; Beata Rzepka
abstract: Abstract Existence of fixed point of a Frobenius-Perron type operator P : L 1 ‚ü∂ L 1 generated by a family { œÜ y } y ‚àà Y of nonsingular Markov maps defined on a œÉ -finite measure space ( I , Œ£ , m ) is studied. Two fairly general conditions are established and it is proved that they imply for any g ‚àà G = { f ‚àà L 1 : f ‚â• 0, and ‚à• f ‚à• = 1}, the convergence (in the norm of L 1 ) of the sequence <m:math xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <m:mtable rowspacing="4pt" columnspacing="1em"> <m:mtr> <m:mtd> <m:mo fence="false" stretchy="false">{</m:mo> <m:msup> <m:mi>P</m:mi> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi>j</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msup> <m:mi>g</m:mi> <m:msubsup> <m:mo fence="false" stretchy="false">}</m:mo> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi>j</m:mi> <m:mo>=</m:mo> <m:mn>1</m:mn> </m:mrow> <m:mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> <m:mi mathvariant="normal">‚àû</m:mi> </m:mrow> </m:msubsup> </m:mtd> </m:mtr> </m:mtable> </m:math> $\begin{array}{} \{P^{j}g\}_{j = 1}^{\infty} \end{array} $ to a unique fixed point g 0 . The general result is applied to a family of C 1+ Œ± -smooth Markov maps in ‚Ñù d .

title: On non-resistive limit of 1D MHD equations with no vacuum at infinity
authors: Zilai Li; Huaqiao Wang; Yulin Ye
abstract: Abstract In this paper, the Cauchy problem for the one-dimensional compressible isentropic magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) equations with no vacuum at infinity is considered, but the initial vacuum can be permitted inside the region. By deriving a priori ŒΩ (resistivity coefficient)-independent estimates, we establish the non-resistive limit of the global strong solutions with large initial data. Moreover, as a by-product, the global well-posedness of strong solutions for the compressible resistive MHD equations is also established.
